characters: HENRY, JAMES, TOMMY AND ASSORTED HOODS AND THEIR GIRL
CICERO AND REST OF MOB BOSSES
SILHOUETTE OF TOMMY, HENRY AND JAMES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smoky, overdecorated cocktail lounge and nightclub on Queens Boulevard. Sergio Franchi is in full voice on the JUKEBOX. It is after midnight. It has been a long night. Balloons and empty glasses litter the place. BILLY BATTS, a 50-year-old hood in an out-of-date suit, holding court at the bar. We see a younger, more sharply-dressed HOOD walk in with a beehive girl friend and hug Batts.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: -Billy. You look beautiful. Welcome home.

dialogues.speaker: BATTS
dialogues.text: (laughing and turn- ing to the bartender) What are you having? Give what they're drinking. ‘em We see four other men, including HENRY HILL and JAMES CONWAY, standing near Billy Batts at the bar, raise their glasses in salute. TOMMY DEVITO and ancther beehive blonde enter. Billy Batts looks up and sees Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: BATTS
dialogues.text: Hey, look at him. Tommy. You grew up.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (preening a little) Billy, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: BATTS
dialogues.text: (smiling broadly at Tommy and the girl) Son of a bitch. Get over here. Tommy walks over and Billy, too aggressively, grabs Tommy around the neck. Tommy doesn't like it.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (forcing a laugh) Hey, Billy. Watch the suit.

dialogues.speaker: BATTS
dialogues.text: (squeezing Tommy's cheek, a little too hard) Listen to him. ‘Watch the suit,' he says.

dialogues.speaker: ., (MORE)
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BATTS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A little pisser I've known all my life. Hey, Tommy, don't get too big.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Don't go busting my balls. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: BATTS
dialogues.text: (laughing, to the crowd at the bar) Busting his balls? (to Tommy) If I was busting your balls, I'd send you home for your shine box. Tommy's smile turns to a glare as he realizes Billy is making fun of him. The men at the bar are roaring with laughter. His girl is looking glumly at her shoes.

dialogues.speaker: BATTS
dialogues.text: (to the hoods at the bar) You remember Tommy's shines? The kid was great. He made mirrors.

dialogues.speaker: _ TOMMY
dialogues.text: (almost a threat) No more shines, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: BATTS
dialogues.text: Come ooonnn. Tommeeee. We're only kidding. You can't take a joke? Come ooonn. We see that Tommy is still angry, but begins to relax with Billy's apparent apology, but as soon as Billy sees that Tommy is beginning to relax, he contemptuously turns his back on Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: BATTS
dialogues.text: (facing the bar) Now get the hell home and get your shine box. Henry quickly steps in front of Tommy who is about to explode. Batts is facing the bar and does not see just how furious Tommy has become.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (gently. wrestling Tommy away from the bar) Come on, relax. He's drunk. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He's been locked up for six years.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I don't give a shit. The guy’s got no right.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Tommy. He doesn't mean anything. Forget about it.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (trying to wrestle past Henry) He's insulting me. Rat bastard. He's never been any fuckin’ good.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Tommy. Come on. Relax.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (te Henry) Keep him here. I'm going for a bag. Tommy roughly grabs his girl's arm and storms out.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: {rejoining James and Billy Batts at the bar) . Batts. I'm sorry. Tommy gets loaded. He doesn't mean any disrespect.

dialogues.speaker: BATTS
dialogues.text: He's got a hot head. We see the last two guests get up to leave. Henry puts another dollar in the jukebox and moves back behind the bar and starts to total the register receipts.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE OF SUITE
dialogues.text: From HENRY'S POV behind the bar, we see the guests leave and suddenly we see Tommy in the doorway. Henry walks around the bar and approaches Tommy. We see James and Batts are still seated at bar with their backs to the door.

dialogues.speaker: BATTS
dialogues.text: They're fucking mutts. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see James nod.

dialogues.speaker: BATTS
dialogues.text: I seen them. They walk around like big shots and they don't know shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guy gets half a load on. He mouths off.

dialogues.speaker: BATTS
dialogues.text: When I was a kid, I swear on my mother, you mouth off, you got your fucking legs broke. cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: approaching Tommy who is carrying a large folded package under one arm. Tommy, followed by Henry, walks over to the bar where James and Bill Batts are talking. Tommy drops the package on the floor. Billy Batts looks up. James turns around and sees that Tommy has a gun in his hand. James immediately grabs Batts's arms and we see Tommy smash the gun into the side of Batts's head. We see Tommy hit Batts again and again as James continues to hold Batts's arms.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (to Henry, while pinning Batts's arms} Quick! Lock the door. We see Tommy club Batts to the ground with James holding Batts's arms.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: locking the door.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BATTS'S INERT FORM
dialogues.text: on the floor. We see Tommy unfold the package he had dropped near the bar. It is a plastic, flower-printed mattress cover. Tommy and James start putting Batts's legs into the mattress cover. Henry is standing over them as James and Tommy struggle to fit Batts's body in the mattress cover.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What are we going to do with him? We can't dump him in the street.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (to Henry) Bring the car ‘round back. I ‘know a place upstate they'll never find him. . Tommy is looking brightly at Henry, as he and James finally zip Batts in the mattress cover.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I didn't want to get blood on your floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. The open trunk of Henry's car. The mattress cover is being shoved into the trunk by the three men. It is heavy work.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Batts's made. His whole crew is going to be looking for him. This is fucking bad.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: There's a shovel at my mother's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness in the kitchen. We hear noise of doors opening and tools being banged around in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Sshhh. You'll wake ‘er up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the light in the entryway goes on, and we see Tommy's MOTHER, in housecoat, beaming at her son and his friends.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN TABLE
dialogues.text: where Tommy's Mother hovers over the seated Tommy, Henry and James. The table is filled with plates and coffee cups and the debris of dirty dishes.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (to all) Have some more. You hardly touched anything. Did Tommy tell you about my painting? Look. We see her reach next to the refrigerator and pull up a couple of oil paintings she props on the edge of the table.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (proudly) They want me to do a portrait next. I'm gonna do the Mona Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: WINDOW
dialogues.text: where we see Henry's car with the body in‘the trunk, still parked at the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally on their way, Henry is driving. James, in the passenger's seat, and Tommy, in the rear seat, embracing the shovel, are dozing off. The sleepy HUMMING sound of WHEELS is suddenly interrupted by a THUMPING sound. At first, Henry thinks he has a flat, but the THUMPING is too irregular. James awakens. His eyes are on Henry. Tommy leans forward from the rear seat. Silence. THUMP! Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Car pulls off the road onto the grass. Henry, James and Tommy, still holding the shovel, get cut of the car.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! Miserable bastard! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry opens the trunk and steps back. In the trunk light we see the mattress cover squirming around. We hear MUFFLED GROANS.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (raising the shovel) Can you believe this no-good fuck? The prick! He's still alive. Tommy suddenly smashes the shovel into the moving, bloody mattress cover. He smashes it again and again and again. Cursing Batts with every swing.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Rat bastard. (swings shovel) No-good, low-life fuck. Tommy swings shovel again and again. Soon the mattress cover stops squirming and Tommy stops Swinging the shovel. He is exhausted. Tommy and James get back in the car. Henry is facing the open trunk. TILT UP and FREEZE ON Henry's face slamming the trunk shut.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: As far back as I can remember, I always wanted to be a gangster.

dialogues.speaker: MAIN TITLE
dialogues.text: UNFREEZE and --

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: looking out his bedroom window.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: To me, being a gangster was better than being President of the United States.

dialogues.speaker: GRIMY ONE-STORY CABSTAND
dialogues.text: with faded "Pitkin Avenue Cabs" sign above the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's after midnight. We see a half-dozen, immaculately- dressed hoods wearing diamond pinky rings and silk shirts, lounging around the cabstand talking and sipping coffee.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Even before I first wandered into the cabstand for an-after-school job, I knew I wanted to be a part of them. It was there I belonged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a Cadillac pull up the to cabstand. We see the car rise slightly when two huge, dapper hoods get out. On hood #1 we see large diamond pinky ring on a sausage-thick finger. On hood #2 we see a broken-nosed hood's tie hanging loosely across his monogrammed shirt like a silk bandolier.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: To me it meant being somebody in a neighborhood full of nobodies. On the sidewalk we see the two hoods who just got out of the car hug and playfully shove TUDDY VARIO, the sloppily-dressed, solidly-built hood who runs the cabstand.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They weren't like anyone else. They did whatever they wanted. They'd double-park in front of the hydrant and nobody ever gave them a ticket. In the summer when they played cards all night, nobody ever called the cops. We see Tuddy laughingly try to push them away.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Tuddy Vario ran the cabstand and a pizzeria and a few other places for his brother, Paul, who was the boss over everybody in the neighborhood. We see a laughing hood #1 slyly slip behind. Tuddy and grab him around the neck, while hood #2 starts feigning punches to Tuddy's ample midsection. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Tuddy Vario and hoods see that PAUL CICERO, the boss, is standing in the cabstand's doorway. Cicero is a large man, standing six-feet tall and weighing over 240 pounds. He appears even larger.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Paulie might have moved slow, but it was only because he didn't have to move for anybody. Tuddy and the hoods immediately stop horsing around. TITLES CONTINUE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARMELLA HILL, Henry's mother, shoves his books under his arm and pushes him into the hallway. We see Henry's two brothers putting on their jackets and picking up their books and almost tripping over another brother's, MICHAEL, wheelchair. We catch a glimpse of two sisters eating breakfast. We see Henry's construction worker father sipping coffee in kitchen before going to work.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: At first, my parents loved that I found a job across the street. My father, who was Irish, was sent to work at the age of eleven, and he liked that I got myself a job. He always said American kids were spoiled lazy.

dialogues.speaker: CARMELLA
dialogues.text: (to the brood) Come on. Come on. You'll all be late.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And my mother was happy after she found out that the Ciceros came from the same part of Sicily as she did. To my mother, it was the answer to her prayers. We see Henry's mother shove him out the door with his school books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carmella, in doorway, watches Henry go down the block toward school. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: When Henry turns the corner, along with other school-boun youngsters, we see he suddenly stops. The other school children keep walking. Henry carefully sticks his head around the corner. His mother is no longer there. We see Henry race across the street toward the cabstand.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I was the luckiest kid in the world. EXT. CABSTAND - DAY to 9 We see Henry leap into the air to catch a set of car keys.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I could go anywhere. EXT. CABSTAND PARKING LOT - DAY ‘ 10 We see Henry, who can hardly see over the, dashboard, jockeying a mobster's Caddy around the cabstand parking lot. We see other kids, Henry's age, watching Henry, in awe, from behind a fence.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I could do anything. INT. CABSTAND BACKROOM - DAY . iL We see Henry watching two uniformed cops laughing with Tuddy. and some hoods while stuffing whiskey bottles under their tunics.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I knew everybody and everybody Knew me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Henry trying to sip hot espresso coffee just like the big guys, except we see Henry grimace because. the coffee is too het and far too bitter.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But it wasn't too long before my parents changed their minds. For them, the cabstand was supposed to be a part-time job, but for me, it was full-time. cuT TO:  13 14 15 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuddy is folding and placing long sheets with policy bets into a brown paper bag. In the b.g., we see hoods going through boxes of stolen orange and blue cardigan sweaters Henry waits at Tuddy's side until Tuddy finishes making a notation on a slip of paper. Tuddy holds the paper bag in his hands and...

dialogues.speaker: TUDDY
dialogues.text: (to Henry, with a smile) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Henry running out the cabstand door carrying the paper bag. He runs past half a dozen hoods, lounging outside on wooden chairs, wearing orange and blue sweaters.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: People like my father could never understand, but I was a part of something. I belonged. I was treated like a grown-up. Every day I was learning to score.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: (in mock concern) Did you study hard in school today? Did you learn a lot? Huh? Henry is silent and begins backing away.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: I can't hear you, you little liar. (waving the letter) I got this from the school. They say you haven't been there in months. Henry tries to dart past his Father, but he cannot escape. Henry gets a blow on the back of his head. Henry's mother starts to interfere, but is pushed back.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: (beating Henry, but glaring at Carmella) Little lying bastard. Carmella screams. Henry doubles up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Henry's Father keeps pounding away.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My father was always pissed off. He was pissed that he had to work so hard. He was pissed that he made such lousy money. He was pissed that there were seven of us living in a tiny house. But after a while, he was mostly pissed that I hung around the cabstand. He said they were bums and that I was a bum. He said I was going to get into trouble. I used to say I was only running errands after school, but he knew better. He knew what went on at the cabstand and, every once in a while, usually after he got his load on, I had to take a beating. But by then, I didn't care. No matter how many beatings I took, I wouldn't listen to what he said. I don't think I even heard him. The way I saw it, everybody has to take a beating some time. UNFREEZE and continue the beating. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: TUDDY
dialogues.text: What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I can't make any more deliveries. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TUDDY
dialogues.text: Whadda you mean, you can't make any more deliveries? You're going to fuck up everything?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: My father got a letter from the school. He said the next time he'll kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three HOODS and Henry in parked car outside the post office.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: (pointing to one postman) Is that the one?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: (pointing at another) Him?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: No. (pause) There. That's him. That's the guy. Hood #1 and Hood #2 get out of the car and grab the stunned MAILMAN. He loses his hat and spills some mail as they shove him into the car's rear seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuddy Vario is standing in front of a pizza oven. Henry watches the Hoods shove the Mailman against the side of the oven. We see Paul Cicero in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: TUDDY
dialogues.text: (pointing to Henry) You know this kid?

dialogues.speaker: MAILMAN
dialogues.text: (barely able to speak) Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GOOD FELLAS - Rev. 6/28/89 14. 18 CONTINUED: “Bes 18.

dialogues.text: nods, and the Hoods’ pull and shove the Mailman -

dialogues.text: eg dge allegiance tothe Hise and ‘sit through good — ‘government bulishit.

dialogues.text: Tuddy.-and Heary running in the. rain.to Paulie’s house. HENRY (V.0.) *. ‘Paulie hated phones... He wouldn't * . have one in his house. . *

dialogues.text: We see Paul Cicero holding court while € a sausage sandwich. : ne

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There are hoods standing around him at a respectful dis- tance. Only Tuddy approaches him with ease. We see a hood talk to Tuddy. We see Tuddy relay the message to Paul. We see Paul say something to Tuddy, who nods back to the hood and then motions to Henry to come over. We see Tuddy bend down a little and whisper in Henry's ear. DOLLY IN ON Paul's face.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hundreds of guys depended on Paulie and he got a piece of everything they made. It was tribute, just like the old country, except they were doing it in America. All they got from Paulie was protection from other guys looking to rip them off. That's what it's all about. That's what the F.B.I. can never understand -- that what Paulie and the organization does is offer protection for people who can't go to the cops. They're like the police department for wiseguys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Tuddy in his car, hand Henry a hammer, some rags, and a five gallon can of gasoline.

dialogues.speaker: TUDDY
dialogues.text: (driving away) I'll be up at the corner. We see Henry BREAK the WINDOWS of about six cars parked facing the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: People looked at me differently. They knew I was with somebody. We see Henry shove the gas-soaked rags through the broken car windows. Henry looks up the block where Tuddy has parked. We see Tuddy (from Henry's POV) look around and nod. Henry immediately begins tossing lighted matchbooks through the smashed car windows. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I didn't have to wait on line at the bakery on Sunday morning anymore for fresh bread. The owner knew who I was with, and he'd come from around the counter, no matter how many people were waiting. I was taken care of first. Suddenly the night EXPLODES in orange brightness. We see Henry begin to run toward Tuddy's car as the cars he has ignited begin to EXPLODE behind him.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Our neighbors didn't park in our driveway anymore, even though we didn't have a car. At thirteen, I was making more money than most of the grownups in the neighborhood. I had more money than I could spend. I had it all. FREEZE ON Henry's silhouette against the darkness like a man in hell.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: One day some of the kids from the neighborhood carried my mother's groceries all the way home for her. It was out of respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry's mother opens door of house, bright daylight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees grey lizard shoes, grey pinstriped trousers, grey silk shirt, Billy Eckstein collar, yellow silk tie, and double-breasted jacket. She looks up and sees Henry's smiling face.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (aghast ) My God! You look like a gangster.

dialogues.speaker: SCREAMING MAN
dialogues.text: running toward the pizzeria, holding his hand.  17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Henry standing near front of store.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (screaming) I've been shot! Help! Help!

dialogues.speaker: TUDDY
dialogues.text: (from rear of store, to Henry) Close the door. Don't let him in, Henry grabs a chair, takes it outside for the man to sit on. and closes the pizzeria door. The man collapses in the seat and Henry immediately starts wrapping the man's shredded and bleeding hand in his apron. The man is turning white and praying.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (soothing the man) It's okay. It's okay. They're getting an ambulance. We see Henry prop the man in his chair and race into the pizzeria for more aprons which he takes outside and wraps around the man's bleeding hand, just as an ambu- lance pulls up. We see Tuddy come up behind Henry as the man is rushed away.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was the first time I had ever seen anyone shot.

dialogues.speaker: TUDDY
dialogues.text: (angry) You're some fucking jerk. We see that Henry is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: TUDDY
dialogues.text: You wasted eight fucking aprons on - that guy.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I remember feeling bad about the guy. But I remember feeling that maybe Tuddy was right. I knew Paulie didn't want anybody dying in the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry is making a ham and cheese sandwich. CAMERA TRACKING THROUGH room full of people playing cards, THROUGH professional card dealers skittering cards across green felt tables, THROUGH bodyguards watching the door, THROUGH Tuddy Vario walking around the tables, THROUGH Paul Cicero standing quietly on the side, THROUGH Henry giving the sandwich to one of the players.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was a glorious time. Wiseguys were all over the place. It was before Apalachin and before Crazy Joey decided to take on a boss and start a war. It was when I met the world. It was when I first met James Conway. CAMERA COMES TO REST when James Conway walks in the door.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: looking at James.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He couldn't have been more than twenty-four or twenty-five at the time, but he was already a legend. He'd walk in the door and everybody who worked the room went wild. He'd give the doorman a hundred just for opening the door. He shoved hundreds in the pockets of the dealers and who ran the games. The bartender got a hundred just for keeping the ice cubes cold. Henry sees Cicero give Conway a hug around the shoulder. Henry sees James handing money to the doorman. Henry watches players timidly move their chairs slightly to make room for James. Henry sees James pull out a wad of bills and sit down.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (to Henry, who is standing near the bar) Hey, kid! Get me a seven and seven. We see Henry make the drink and bring it to James. Cicero is standing next to James. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: (his arm around Henry's shoulder) Henry. Say hello to James Conway. We see James slip a $20 bill in Henry's shirt pocket.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (lifting his drink to Henry) Keep ‘em coming. FREEZE FRAME ON James.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: James was one of the most feared guys in the city. He was first locked up at eleven and was doing hits for mob bosses when he was sixteen. Hits never bothered him. It was business. But what he really loved to do was steal. I mean, he actually enjoyed it. James was the kind of guy who rooted for the bad guys in the movies. He was one of the city's biggest hijackers. Clothes. Razor blades. Booze. Cigarettes, Shrimp and lobsters. Shrimp and lobsters were the best. They went ast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trailer truck is stopped at a light in a deserted area near JFK Airport. We see the driver being quietly led to a car where James Conway is standing. We see James routinely take the driver's wallet. There is absolutely no resistance.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And almost all of them were gimmie's.

dialogues.speaker: WALLET
dialogues.text: We see James put a $50 bill. in the driver's wallet. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They called him James the Gent. The drivers loved him. They used to tip him off about the really good loads. Of course, everybody got a piece. And when the cops assigned a whole army to stop him... (pause) ..-. James made them partners. cur TO: EXT. CABSTAND PARKING LOT - CLOSEUP - ROWS oF CIGARETTE 2

dialogues.speaker: CARTONS
dialogues.text: piled inside a large trailer truck. James and Tommy DeVito, a youngster about Henry's age, are moving large cigarette cartons toward truck tail- gate. While James is dressed like a truck driver, Tommy is very nattily dressed in a sharply-cut suit and highly buffed shoes. James and Tommy are loading the cartons into the arms of a woman SCHOOL-CROSSING GUARD who is having difficulty carrying the load.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Tommy. Help the lady. We see Tommy scramble down from the truck and help the School-Crossing Guard to her own car where we see she already had a load of the cartons. We see Henry standing near her car and watching.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL-CROSSING GUARD
dialogues.text: (driving off) Thank you, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: standing between Tommy and Henry.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (to Henry) Say hello to Tommy. You'll do good together.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CAR
dialogues.text: pulling onto the sidewalk where Henry, Tommy and James are standing. The COPS recognize James.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Anything good? Henry watches James smile and toss a couple of cartons of cigarettes into their radio car. The Cops wave and drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Henry busily selling. cartons to workers. Tommy is getting cartons out of the trunk of a car parked nearby. Henry is so busy he can hardly keep the money and cash straight. Instead of the neat roll we saw on James, Henry's cash is a wrinkled mess. Some of it is rolled, some folded, some in different pockets. We see Henry approached by two city DETECTIVES.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: What do you think you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Where did you get these cigarettes?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: , (offering them cartons) It's okay. Detective #1 roughly grabs Henry's arm. Detective #2 grabs Henry's cigarette cartons, We see Henry pull his arm away and one. of the Detectives slaps him across the face. We see that Tommy is about to say something, but runs away instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Tommy talking to Tuddy and assorted hoods at the cabstand. . :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry is waiting along with dozens of hookers, nodding junkies, muggers and shoplifters. When Henry's case is called, we PAN TO a well-dressed mob lawyer. Henry, who has never seen the lawyer before, walks to the prosecutor's, rather than the defendant's table. A court clerk nods him over toward his own lawyer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We see DRIVER get out of truck with ENGINE still RUNNING and leave door open. He nods to Henry who does not respond and the Driver casually walks toward the diner.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: If any of the truckers or airlines gave us trouble, Paulie had his union people scare them with a little strike. It was beautiful. It was an even bigger money-maker than numbers, and James was in charge. Whenever we needed money, we'd rob the airport. To us, it was better than Citibank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Driver rise from debris of breakfast dishes, leave a tip and pay the cashier. He walks out the door toward his truck in the parking lot. HOLD ON the door. Driver rushes back in through the door toward the cashier.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (flushed and agitated) Hurry, gimme the phone. Two niggers just stole my truck.

dialogues.speaker: INT, SONNY BUNZ'S LOUNGE
dialogues.text: A cavernous room within earshot of the airport that looks like a movie nightclub. No matter when you walk into the Bunz Lounge it's always the middle of the night. CAMERA TRACKS PAST the zebra-striped banquettes and bar stools, past sharpy businessmen, bookmakers and hoods.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There was James and Tommy and me. And there was Anthony Stabile, Franky Carbone, Fat Andy, Frankie the Wop, Freddy No Nose, Pete the Killer, Johnny Bianco, Mikey Franzese, and Jimmy Two Times, who got that nickname because he said everything twice. Like, ‘You wanna get the papers, get the papers.’ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRACKS TO the backroom which we see is filled with racks of clothes, boxed television sets, new toaster ovens and stereos. We see MAN rolling racks of fur coats i oom i ook: ike isco

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (to Sonny) Sonny, we got the coats.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (ignoring the Man and to Henry) You got any suits?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Not till Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (closing door to backroom) I need suits.

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDS
dialogues.text: are having a party. There are champagne buckets around the table which is littered with steak and lobster dishes. The table is a mess and everyone is laughing. We see Henry look at his watch and look at the lounge's entrance. .

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: For us to live any other way was nuts. To us, those goody-good people who worked shitty jobs for bum paychecks, who took the subway to work every day and worried about their bills, were dead. They were suckers. They had no balls. If we wanted something, we just took it. If anyone complained twice, they got hit so bad they never complained again. It was routine. You didn’t even think about it. Cur To: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOORWAY OF BUNZ LOUNGE
dialogues.text: We see FRENCHY McMAHON, a beefy man in a leather windbreaker, enter. We see Henry get up and go over to greet him. cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: Henry and Frenchy embrace. Frenchy is still wearing his Air France cargo worker's coveralls under his leather jacket and we see the "Air France" logo and the name "Frenchy" in script over the coverall's breast pocket.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHY
dialogues.text: (trying to whisper above the din) It's all there. I can get you past the alarms and I can get the ey. We see Henry turn to table and wave at James to join them at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: TABLE
dialogues.text: We see James get up and go to the bar. We see Tommy at the table with SONNY BUNZ, the owner, hovering around. Sonny Bunz is holding a thick sheaf of bills. We see Sonny timidly approach Tommy by whispering in his ear. In the b.g., we also see the face of a terrified waiter.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (putting his arm around Sonny's shoulder) It's okay. Put it on the tab.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (whispering with fear all over his face) Tommy, it's not just this. Tommy, please. It's seven grand here. We see Tommy just stare menacingly at Sonny. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (he started, he might as well finish) Tommy, I need the money, Tommy, Please. I owe the world.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (leaping from the table in a rage) You sonofabitch fuck. Are you calling me a deadbeat? The money I spent here? Embarrassing me in front of my friends. You miserable fuck. {turning to his pals) Can you believe this bastard? (back to terrified Sonny) Ungrateful fuck! I oughta break your fucking legs! We see Sonny Bunz flee toward his office, with Tommy making a half-hearted gesture to follow, but instead, he walks over and joins Henry, James and Frenchy at the bar. He is smiling.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCHY
dialogues.text: {to Tommy) Hey, Tommy. Have a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Sonny Bunz meekly seated at table facing Paul Cicero. Henry is standing behind Sonny Bunz for support.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: (groaning) If you knew those fucking kids. They're nuts. Especially that Tommy. What am I going to do with them?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (sweating) But I'm worried. I'm hearing all kinds of things. Paulie. You know me all my life. I've always done the right thing.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: You think that matters? You think they give a shit about anything? The little bastards. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: But it isn't right, Paulie. That Tommy he's making trouble for me all over town. I can't go here. I can't go there.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: You? You think you're the only one? I've talked to them a million times, but they don't listen.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (weakly) But, Paulie, please.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: (barely listening) Someday they'll get what's coming to them. That's the only way they'll stop.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (pleading) Paulie, I swear, I'm afraid. The guy's nuts. What do I have to do? Whatever I gotta do, I'll do.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: (arms outstretched like a saint) What can I do? If I could do something, don't you think I would? Sonny looks up at Henry for support.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (to Sonny) Tell him, It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I was thinking that maybe you could come in with me. Take a piece of the place. If you were with me, maybe then they'd have to lay off.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: What do I need... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I mean it. We could do good.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: You want a partner?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see trucks with liquor, beer, sides of beef, even furniture like bar stools and large mirrors being unloaded and delivered into the front door.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Now the guy's got Paulie for a partner. Any problems, he goes to Paulie. Trouble with the bill? He can go to Paulie. Trouble with the cops? Deliveries? Tommy? He ean call Paulie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Henry and two hoods from cabstand checking the cases of liquor being delivered into the lounge. The entire room is filled floor to ceiling with cases of whiskey, wine, crates of lobster, and shrimp, and stacks of table linen and sides of beef. The place looks like a warehouse.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But now the guy has got to come up with Paulie's money every week, no matter what. Business bad? Fuck you, pay me. You had a fire? Fuck you, pay me. The place hit by lightning? Fuck you, pay me. Also, Paulie could do anything. Especially run up bills on the joint's credit. Why not? Nobody's gonna pay for it anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see cases of liquor, wine, etc., being carried out of the rear door of the lounge by hoods from the cabstand and loaded onto U-Haul trucks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: As soon as the deliveries are made in the front door, you move the stuff out the back and sell it at a discount. You take a two hundred dollar case of booze and sell it for a hundred. It doesn't matter. It's all profit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry, James and Tommy are standing around the small workman's table. There is no desk. The office looks denuded of furniture. A lawyer is going over papers. A terrified, unshaven Sonny Bunz is seated behind the desk. The lawyer is showing him where to sign.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And, finally, when there's nothing left, when you can't borrow another buck from the bank or buy another case of booze, you bust the joint out.

dialogues.speaker: HANDS
dialogues.text: making rolls of toilet paper being kneaded into long rolls with Sterno.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY AND TOMMY
dialogues.text: shoving wads of Sterno paper into the ceiling rafters.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You light a match. Cut To:

dialogues.speaker: MATCH
dialogues.text: lighting rolls of Sterno paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street is empty. Henry and Tommy are seated in Henry's car. They are watching the Bunz Lounge. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (to Henry) You gotta help me. Okay? This girl I told you about? Helene? She's from the Five Towns. She's Jewish. She won't go out with me alone. Can you believe this shit? She's fucking prejudiced, but she's built. She's never been out with an Italian before. She says she'll only go out on a double date with her girl friend. You believe this shit? But you gotta see her. I mean, she's beautiful. -

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (laughing) Will you get the fuck out of here.—

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Is it my fault she won't go out without her girl friend? For Chrissake. Come on. You don't even have to stay. Jeesuz! What's the big deal?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Tommy...

dialogues.speaker: HENRY AND TOMMY
dialogues.text: watching smoke coming out of basement windows of Bunz Lounge.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: (back to conversation) I swear you don't have to do nothing. You. just show up and then leave. What do you think, I want you around? All I need is for you to get me started. We hear CAR ENGINE START.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a red damask restaurant. Tommy and Henry are seated on the outside of.a U-shaped banquet with their two girls, Helene and Karen, seated inside. Helene is being wooed and pawed by a blissful Tommy. Helene is enjoying every bit of Tommy's undivided attention. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Karen has not touched her melted baked Alaska and is looking directly at Henry. Henry is stirring his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I had a meeting with Tuddy around eleven o'clock and here I am a back-up guy.

dialogues.speaker: . KAREN
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Have more coffee. It'll wake you up.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I couldn't wait to get away. I was ordering the dessert when they were eating dinner. When they were having coffee, I was asking for a check.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (to Henry, while hugging Helene) Isn't she great? Isn't this great? Let's do it tomorrow night? Okay?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I couldn't stand him. I thought he was really obnoxious. He kept fidgeting around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Henry pushing Karen into the car.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Before it was even time to go home he was pushing me into the car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Henry hurrying Karen out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... and then pulling me out. It was ridiculous. But Helene and Tommy had made us promise to meet them again on Friday night. We agreed... Of course, when Friday night came around, Henry stood me up..  43 44 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Tommy, Helene and Karen seated at a table set for four.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We were a trio instead of a double-date that night, but I made Tommy take me looking for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hot night. The hoods have moved to the sidewalk where we see them sitting in sleeveless underwear, watching the street. ‘We see Henry leave the cabstand when suddenly a CAR SCREECHES up on the sidewalk directly in front of him. The hoods scatter and we see that Henry is terrified.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (charging out of the door, Screaming) You've got some nerve. Standing me up. Nobody does that to me. Who do you think you are? A big shot?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: who sees Tommy and Helene in the car, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (embarrassed and defensive) I didn't know. I swear. I thought it was next week.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Liart

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: who sees the wiseguys laughing.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Take it easy. We can talk about it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: She's screaming on the street and I mean loud, but she looked good. She had these viclet eyes. I remember she's screaming, but mostly I'm looking at her eyes. They were just like Elizabeth Taylor's. That's what everybody said.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (furious) Talk? To you? After what you did!

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I thought you were going to stand me up. You looked bored. You didn't say anything. What did you expect. Tommy was all over me. Right? We see Karen relax for a second.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Come on, let me make it up.

dialogues.speaker: CROSS AROUND MAN'S NECK
dialogues.text: and TILT UP. Henry is all smiles and slicked-up, stand- ing in the door wearing a grey suit and open-necked black silk shirt with a gold cross on chain.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (filled with alarm) Button your shirt, quick! Hurry. Henry buttons his shirt as Karen's Mother comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Ma, this is my friend, Henry Hill.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: My daughter says you're half- Jewish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry gives the keys and a rolled-up twenty dollar bill to the doorman at the building across the street and steers Karen toward the Copa. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: What're you doing? What about the car?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (while pushing her through the crowd waiting to get in) He watches it for me. It's better than waiting at a garage. We see Henry deftly steer Karen away from the Copa’s main entrance and down the basement steps. A huge bodyguard, eating a sandwich in the stairwell gives Henry a big "hello." We see Henry walk right through the basement kitchen, which is filled with Chinese and Latino cooks and dishwashers who pay no attention. Karen is being dragged along, open-mouthed, at the scene. Henry starts up a stained kitchen staircase through a pair of swinging doors and suddenly Karen sees she is inside the main room. The harried maitre d’ (he is surrounded by customers clamoring for their tables) waves happily at Henry and signals to a CAPTAIN. We see a table held aloft by two waiters wedging their way toward the stage and plant the table smack in front of what had until that moment been a ringside table. As Henry leads Karen to their seat, she sees that he is nodding and shaking hands with many of the other guests. We see Henry quietly slip twenty dollar bills to the waiters.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (sitting down) You gave them twenty dollars each? We see the Captain approach with champagne.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: This is with Mister Tony, over there.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Where, over there?

dialogues.speaker: . CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Over there, over there. Karen watches Henry turn around and wave at a 280-pound hood.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: What do you do? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (toasting Karen and clinking glasses) I'm in construction.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (taking his-hands) They don't feel like you're in construction. Henry turns to the stage where the lights begin to dim and Henny Youngman walks out.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'm a union delegate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On loading platform we see Henry and Tommy dressed in Air France coveralls. Henry is carrying a large suitcase. Suddenly we see Frenchy McMahon come through a door, slip Henry a key and lead them back into the office area near the entrance. Henry goes to the door marked "SECURITY AREA” that Frenchy points out and opens it with the key. Henry and Tommy go inside.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY AND TOMMY
dialogues.text: coming out with the suitcase, close the door and walk right past Frenchy without saying a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the suitcase open on the desk. We see Cicero, James, Henry and Tommy standing around, wreathed in smiles. Henry is counting stacks of cash, spreading them all over the desk.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Air France made me. We walked out with four hundred and twenty thousand dollars without.a gun. And we did the. right thing. Henry counts up $420,000 and slides ten packages of $100 bills in front of Cicero who stands up and proudly kisses Henry on the cheek. ° (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: James and Tommy, both aglow with the moment, look on. It is clear that Henry has come of age.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: (to Henry) It's a lot of money for a kid. If anyone asks, just say you won it shooting crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry and Karen are at a sun-drenched table after paper- cup and paper plate lunch where Henry is trying to pay cash.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (touching Henry's arm) No. No. You've got to sign for it. We see athletic young men and women in white clothes carrying tennis and squash rackets walk by. One young man, Bruce, says hello to Karen. She introduces him to Henry.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (after Bruce walks on) He lives across the street.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMPAGNE
dialogues.text: being sent to table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS TO stage where we see singer's back and Henry and Karen at a luxurious ringside table with linen, silver, and crystal.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: One night Billy Daniels sent us champagne. There was nothing like it. I didn't think that there was anything strange in any of this -- you know, a twenty-one-year-old kid with such connections.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry and Karen are sipping champagne from Copa glasses in car parked outside her house.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He was an exciting guy. He was really nice. He introduced me to everybody. Everybody wanted to be nice to him. And he knew how to handle it:

dialogues.speaker: SALON
dialogues.text: We see Morris swimming the length of a pool, surrounded by adoring models in bathing suits.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) They'll stay put even in a typhoon. And I should know. I'm the president of the company. We see Morris and Henry standing near TELEVISION set, COMMERCIAL is repeated over and over. Morris is taking bets on the phone and complaining to Henry. We see an agitated James Conway in b.g. poking at wigs and looking toward Henry and Morris.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: (complaining sotto voce to Henry while taking bets on the phone) James's busting my chops. (into phone) Okay, give ‘em eight to five on Cleveland. (hangs up phone and to Henry, while nervously eyeing in the other room) He wants three points over the vig. From me? I don't believe this shit?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (pleading) Morris. Please. You know James. You borrowed his money. Pay ‘em. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: (so outraged his voice gets louder) I didn't agree to three points over the vig. What am I, nuts? I didn't need it that much.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (getting exasperated) What are you gonna do? Fight with him? He wants his money.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Fuck ’em. I never paid points. I always did the right thing. Did I ever bust his balls? Did I? Did I? I could have dropped a dime a million times, and I wouldn't have had to pay dick.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (getting annoyed) Morris, you're talking crazy. Drop a dime? Call the cops? Don't even let anybody hear such bullshit. Why don't you just pay the man his money and shut the fuck up. We see James in b.g. start toward Henry and Morris when he hears Henry raise his voice. We see James come up behind Morris and wrap the long telephone extension cord around Morris's neck. We see Morris's eye begin to pop. We see Henry try to get his hands between the wire and Morris's neck while trying to get James to stop.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (total fury) You got money for your bullshit television, don't you? I gotta watch you swimming back and forth on T.V. all night long, don’t I? You got money for that, but you don't have my money?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: James. He'll be okay. He's good for it. Relax. We see Morris nodding in agreement that he will pay. Suddenly, the PHONE RINGS. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We see James, Henry and Morris frozen for.a second. see James relax the cord. We see Morris pick up the phone. The extension cord is still loosely wrapped around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: (handing Henry the phone) It's for you. Henry takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (fury crosses his face) Wait there. Henry races out the door, leaving Morris and James docilely looking after him as he runs out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Karen waiting at booth as Henry pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (erying and dishev- elled) I've known him all my life. He just started grabbing at me. He wouldn't stop. And when I hit him across the nose with my shoe, he got mad and shoved me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry's car is parked at the curb. A new red Corvette is parked across the street.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Go inside. I'll be right there.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Get inside! When Karen gets out of the car, we see Henry reach under the seat for a snub-nose .38 revolver. 52 53 54 55  56 57 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Henry walk down driveway to the back yard area where BRUCE and two of his brothers are talking. Bruce sees Henry and walks toward him. Bruce's two brothers are smirking.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: What do you want? They get close.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (annoyed and menacing) Hey! Fucko! You want something? With absolutely no warning, Henry reaches out and grabs Bruce's hair with one hand and pulls his gun out of his waistband with the other. In almost one motion, Henry smashes the gun across Bruce's face. Teeth fall from Bruce's mouth. The two brothers, still not seeing the gun, start toward Henry, but Henry continues to pound the gun into Bruce's face like a dinner gong. Bruce's head is still off the ground only because Henry refuses to let go of his hair. Bruce's brothers realize Henry has a gun. They freeze and back off.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (0.8S.)
dialogues.text: (from a window) Help! Police! He's got a gun! Police! Quick! Murder! Henry drops Bruce to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Karen standing at the side door as Henry races up and puts something in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (panting) Here, hold this. We see Karen look down.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN'S HAND
dialogues.text: holding gun.

dialogues.speaker: GUN
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I know there are women, like my best friends, who would have gotten out of there the minute their boyfriend gave them a gun to hide. 'Feh! You and your gun. Get out of here. Who needs you?' That's what they would have said to him. But I didn't. I've got to admit the truth. It turned me on. We see Karen look around to make sure no one else has seen her. She then leans over and hides the gun in the milk box at her feet. ,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see hands carefully wrapping a white linen table napkin around some object. We see the napkin and object placed on the floor. We see a man's heel come down and smash the object, which turns out to be.a wine glass. We are at a small Jewish living room wedding with a canopy and rabbi and it was Henry who broke the glass as a part of the ritual. Karen's parents are glumly looking on. Henry's. parents are even glummer. Only Michael, Henry's brother in the wheelchair, looks pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paulie Cicero, Frenchy, Morris Kessler, Tommy DeVito, and all of their wives and fiancees are present. PAN FROM Henry's and Karen's parents sitting uneasily at different tables.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL CICERO
dialogues.text: “presiding at a sort of line, introducing Karen to the Cicero family and guests. Henry stands behind Karen, smiling proudly.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was like he had two families. The first time I was introduced to them all at once, it was crazy. Paulie and his brothers had lots of sons and nephews and almost all of them were named Peter or Paul. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was unbelievable. There must have been two dozen Peters and Pauls at the wedding. Plus, they were all married to girls named Marie, and they named all their daughters Marie. By the time I finished meeting everybody, I thought I was drunk.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY AND KAREN'S TABLE
dialogues.text: Seated nearby are a beaming James Conway and his wife,

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY CONWAY
dialogues.text: We see Cicero approach and hand Karen an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: Here. This is for you.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (leoking down at the envelope) Paulie, you shouldn't. We see that Cicero's envelope is richly embossed with hearts and flowers and has a clear window in front through which she can see several neatly-folded hundred dollar bills. When Karen looks up, she sees that every wiseguy and his wife are lined up before her and that they are all holding envelopes with clear windows in ‘ront .

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: perspiring a little as she accepts and thanks the dozens of wiseguys giving her the envelopes. We also see Henry has opened a plastic supermarket shopping bag under the table where he is stuffing the envelopes just as soon as Karen accepts them.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY AND KAREN
dialogues.text: getting up to dance.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (whispering) My bag. My bag. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (amused) What bag?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (desperate) The bag with the envelopes.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (chiding) Oh that. Don't worry about that. Nobody's gonna steal it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Karen propped up, awake, in a chair. Her father is seated on a sofa, asleep. KAREN'S MOTHER is looking out the window.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: He didn't call?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: He's with his friends.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: What kind of person doesn't call?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: He's a grown man. He doesn't have to call every five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: If he was so grown up he'd get you two an apartment.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Don't bring that up. You're the one who wanted us here.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: (ignoring the charge) “ Look. He's got the whole house in an uproar.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: dozing on sofa. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAREN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: He's got your father upset. Good thing he doesn't have to go to work in the morning. Is this what he deserves?

dialogues.speaker: KARE
dialogues.text: Ma! Please! You're-driving: me crazy.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Driving you crazy? Don't get me started. You're here a month and sometimes I know he doesn't come home at all. What kind of people are these?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Ma! Stop! What.do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Do?. What can you do? What did you expect? He wasn't Jewish. Did you know how they live? Your father would never stay out this late without calling. In thirty years he never stayed out all night.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: sleeping on sofa.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Stayed out? Daddy never went out at all.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE UP
dialogues.text: We hear CAR DOOR OPEN in front of house.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN AND KAREN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: open the door together and we see Henry standing in door- way, a little drunk. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Behind Henry we see a car with Tommy DeVito still parked at the curb. Karen is happy to see him. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: (angrily) Where were you? Where have you been? Why didn't you call? We were all worried to death! A married man doesn't stay out like this! We see Henry look at Karen, look at Karen's Mother and turn around and get back in the car and drive away. Karen begins to cry. Karen's father sleepily comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: (as Henry drives away) Normal people don't live this way.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: Karen and most of the women we saw at the wedding are at Mickey's cosmetic party. There are large cardboard posters of glamorous models using the cosmetics at Mickey's feet.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We weren't married to nine-to-five guys, but the first time I realized how different was when Mickey had a hostess party.

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY
dialogues.text: brushing another woman, ANGIE's, hair while showing off a new brush.

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY
dialogues.text: (to Angie) Angie, sweetheart, you want it fluff?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE'S TIRED FACE
dialogues.text: black-ringed eyes and thin mouth.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: He's the one with the hands. I'd like te smack his face.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: The red-haired guy? He looks like a farmer?  -

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: Sonofabitch. I swear. You can't go through the gate without his hands. I told him. Keep your fucking hands off, you sonofabitch, or I'll cut them off. We see the women laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: He don't know how lucky he is. If I just mentioned it to Vince, I don't even want to know.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: That's the problem. How can you mention it? Vince'd kill him.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: You think I don't know? You think I like to keep this inside? But I gotta, or he'll kill the miserable bastard and he’1l be there for life. It's disgusting what you have to put up with.

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY
dialogues.text: (while fluffing Angie's hair) Look at Jeannie's kid.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: What? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY
dialogues.text: The oldest one. He was in an argument. A lousy ten-dollar card game. The kid pulls out a gun. It goes, The. kid gets killed. The grandmother hears it and finds out he's been arrested. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: talking.

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She has a heart attack, She drops dead right on the spot. Now Jeannie's got a husband and son in jail and a mother in the funeral parlor.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: But he was always a bad kid, that one.

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY
dialogues.text: No. Come on. It was the younger one that was the bad one.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (continuing over dialogue) They had bad skin and wore too much makeup. I mean they didn't look very good. They looked beat up.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You never saw teeth like that where I was growing up and the stuff they wore was thrown together and cheap. A lot of pants suits and double-knits. And they talked about how rotten their kids were and about beating them with broom handles and leather belts, but that the kids still didn't pay any attention. When Henry picked me up, I was dizzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see they are getting ready for bed.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I don't know. I don't know if I could live that way. What if, God forbid, you go to prison. Mickey said Jeannie's husband --

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (angrily interrupting) Are you nuts? (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jeannie's husband went to the can just to get away from her, she's such a pain in the ass. Let me tell you. Nobody goes to jail unless they want to, unless they make. themselves get caught. They ‘do stuff with the: wrong people. They don't have things organized. You know who goes to jail? Nigger stickup men. That's who. And / they only get caught because they .. fall asleep in the getaway car. . Karen looks down. She’s listening.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Listen, we're beginning to make real money for the first time. It's business. Do you think I'm going to walk away from that? Henry puts his arm around Karen and begins to hug her.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: After a while, it all got to be normal. None of it seemed like crimes. It was more that Henry was enterprising. That he and the guys were making a few bucks hustling, while other men were sitting on their asses waiting for handouts. Our husbands weren't brain surgeons. They were blue collar guys, and the only way they could get extra money, real extra money, was to go out and cut a few corners.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY AND TOMMY
dialogues.text: who is carrying a brown paper bag as though it were a gun, pulling a driver out of his truck and shoving him toward another hood who pushes him into the rear seat of a car where we see another hood.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY AND TOMMY
dialogues.text: getting into the truck.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: where we see the truck drive off.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK
dialogues.text: where we see the paper bag in Tommy's hand explode in a red burst as he wildly FIRES SHOTS into the air. We hear Henry's laughter.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And we were also very close. I mean, there were never any outsiders around. Absolutely never! And being together all the time made everything seem even more normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Karen looking at a search warrant being shown to her by detectives who are being very polite. The children are looking on.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There was always a little harassment. They always wanted to talk to Henry about this or that. They'd come with their subpoenas and warrants and make me sign. But mostly they were just looking for a handout. A few bucks to keep things quiet, not matter what they found.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (signing the paper) Can I make you some coffee? The detectives smile and, taking off their hats, walk into the house where kids and Karen resume watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I always asked them if they wanted coffee. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Some of the wives, like Mickey Conway, used to curse at them and spit on the floor. Imagine. She'd spit on her own floor. That never made any sense to me. It was better to be polite and call the lawyer. Cut To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In background we see the detectives going through the house, cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see James and Mickey and Henry and Karen and Tuddy and wife, Tommy and girlfriend, Morris and Karen Kessler, Franky Carbone and wife and the assorted children, all wearing party hats and blowing out the candles on nine- year-old James Conway Jr.'s huge layer cake.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We all did everything together and we were always the same crowd. Anniversaries. Christenings. We only went to each other's houses.

dialogues.speaker: SNAPSHOT
dialogues.text: of James hugging Karen and Mickey at table.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The women played cards. When my kids were born, James and Mickey were always the first at the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: SNAPSHOT
dialogues.text: of beaming James, Mickey and Henry embracing against the window of maternity hospital while a nurse holds up a baby. Mickey is in tears.

dialogues.speaker: . KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: When we went to the Islands or Vegas for vacation, we always went together,

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SNAPSHOT
dialogues.text: of James and Mickey and Henry and Karen in bathsuits standing next to their poolside chairs holding tall Trader Vic's-style drinks with tiny umbrellas and pineapple sticking out of them.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It got to be normal. I got to where I was even proud that I had the kind of husband who was willing to go out and risk his neck just to get us the little extras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRACKS row after row of neatly hung suits and - sports jackets and racks of sharp shoes. We see Henry getting undressed. He neatly hangs his jacket and then lifts the front of his sport shirt to his neck, revealing thick packets of crisp $50 and $100 bills he has wedged all around his waist.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: But I got my mother to watch the kids tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRACKS PAST rows of Karen's dresses, pants suits, biouses, shoes and fur coats.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I told you I can't.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: We see Henry, now shaved and dressed in a different suit. He is on his way out.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (annoyed) I'm gonna need. some money.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: How much? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We see Karen hold her thumb and forefinger about an inch apart. We see Henry take about an inch and a half of money from his inside jacket pocket, slap it on the table and go out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A plush, overdecorated cocktail lounge and nightclub on Queens Boulevard, where we hear Sergio Franchi on the jukebox. (NOTE: Replay the opening of the film at 9 times normal speed -- Henry slamming the truck closed.)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: For most of the guys, killing got to be accepted. They were routine. Murder was the only way everybody stayed in line. It was the ultimate weapon. “You got out of line, you got whacked. Everyone knew the rules,

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: smashing gun into Bill Batt's head.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But sometimes, even if people didn’t get out of line, they'd get whacked. Hits just became a habit for some guys. It didn't take anything to get yourself killed.

dialogues.speaker: SILHOUETTE OF TOMMY, HENRY AND JAMES
dialogues.text: stuffing Billy's body into the truck.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Guys would get into arguments over nothing and before you knew it, one of them was dead. They were shooting each other all the time. Shooting people was a normal thing. It was no big deal. cuUuT TO: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY'S MOTHER'S KITCHEN
dialogues.text: and breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You didn't have to do anything and nobody was immune. You just had to be there.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: smashing shovel into soft, bloodied mattress cover in the trunk of the car.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But we had a problem with Billy Batts. This was a touchy thing. Tommy had killed a made man. Billy was a part of the Gambino crew and untouchable. cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We. see Tommy, Henry and James burying Batts.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Before you could touch a made guy, you had to have a good reason. There had to be a sitdown. And you better get an okay, or you'd be the one who got whacked. Henry slams down trunk.

dialogues.speaker: TABLE
dialogues.text: being quickly set up by waiters and maitre d' as Henry, Tommy, Franky Carbone, and Joe Manri sit down. In b.g., we see older hoods with young showgirl types. We see JANICE, a cherry California blonde, and some girl- friends seated at a table directly behind Henry's table.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: and as stage lights dim:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Saturday night was for wives, but Friday night at the Copa was always for the girlfriends.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY'S TABLE
dialogues.text: Henry is now sitting next to Janice. Tommy is with GIRL #1. Carbone is with GIRL #2.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Last week I saw Sammy Davis. What a performer. You gotta see hin. You gotta catch him. He does imitations I swear you'd think it was the real people.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah, the way he moves. It's unbelievable. I mean, you can understand how a white girl could fall for him.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I don't mean me. Not me. I just mean, you can see how some girls could. Like that Swedish girl. You can see how she fell for him. You can see how he has this, this, personality.

dialogues.speaker: COPA STAGE
dialogues.text: spotlight. Bobby Darren is singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry's convertible pulls up. Henry has his arm around. Janice's neck. We .see them go into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday. There are lots of relatives and friends present. Henry and Karen arrive. Karen is carrying their new baby and Henry has his two-year-old daughter by the hand. A great fuss is made over the new baby and over Karen by the women, including Cicero's wife. Cicero puts an arm around Henry and leads him into an alcove.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: What did you hear about that thing?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What thing? The Brooklyn thing?

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: No. No. The guy from downtown.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: The guy from near where Christie used to live?

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: No. The other one. The one who disappeared up the block from Christie. The one they made a beef on.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Oh! Him.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: You: know the one I mean?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Sure. That guy. I know him.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: That Batts was a miserable fuck, but his people are looking still for him.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Yeah. I know. I even looked into it myself. Nobody knows what the fuck happened to him. He came in the joint that one night and then he disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: Well, keep your eyes open. They're busting my balls looking for the fuck.  72 73 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry and Janice, with the crew, are drinking. Morris Kessler is reluctantly paying off a bet at the bar. James calls Henry aside.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We got a problem. That thing we took care of upstate?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (surprised) Paulie was just taking about him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Well, we gotta dig him up again.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (shocked) What?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: The guy just sold the property. They're gonna build condominiums and I don't want anybody digging up the little bastard.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (horrified) It's been six months.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: It's still better than letting somebody find him.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (nodding in agree- ment and concern) If Paulie finds out, we got problems.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Fuck Paulie. If Batts' crew finds we whacked him, we got real problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hot summer night. The car trunk is open. Henry, James and Tommy are struggling with shovels. Henry, sickened by the stench, is wearing his handkerchief over his nose and mouth. Henry looks at James and Tommy. They do not appear to be bothered by.the stench.  74 75 76 7 57. EXT. HENRY AND KAREN’S SUBURBAN HOME 74 Henry is hosing out the trunk of his car. . He has all of the mats, the spare tire, and jack out of the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: What happened to the car?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (annoyed at Karen's prying) I hit. a skunk. Henry sprinkles in a bottle of perfume and slams the trunk shut. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Janice showing off her new apartment to the giris, including SANDY, a sexy, dark-haired girl. We hear Henry, Tommy, Carbone and Manri laughing in b.g. The apartment is decorated in Ocean Parkway Ming. There are thick velvet-covered sofa and blue-glass ‘coffee table in bedroom and we see a satin-covered, king- size bed with a doll propped against the pillows. We see Janice lean over and show her girlfriends, including Sandy, the red ruffles.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I set up Janice in an apartment around the corner from the Suite. That way I was able to stay over a couple of nights a week. Karen was home with the kids anyway and she never asked any questions anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry is strangling the owner of a bridal shop with his own tie while Tommy and James laugh.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Janice and I were having so much fun, she started screwing up at work, and I had to straighten out her boss a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Janice suddenly lifted off her feet and thrown on the bed. We see Henry and the girls laughing. As Henry lifts Janice off her feet, he winks at Sandy, who smiles back.  58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glazed walls, ornate sconces, and a rumpus room bar. Henry, James, Tommy and other wiseguys are playing cards. Tommy is a little drunk. Spider, a 22-year-old apprentice hood, is waiting on the players, bringing them drinks. The sort of thing we saw Henry doing earlier. Tommy is feeling expansive. He throws his jacket open to reveal a gun tucked in his belt.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Spider. C'mon, get me a seven and seven. We see Spider deliver a drink to Henry and slowly back toward the bar.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Spider. What did I say? Did I say I was dying over here? Come on. Move it. Don't walk, dance. (to his fellow players) Did you ever see in the cowboy movies where they make them dance? Did you see The Oklahoma Kid, the only cowboy movie Cagney ever made? Come on, dance, you varmit. We see Tommy taking out his guns.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: Tommy, don't fuck around.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Yahooo.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Tommy, don't fuck around. Put the gun away. Tommy!

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: No, no. It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Tommy, come on. Put the gun away.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: No. It's okay. Just watch this. Watch it. The GUN EXPLODES and we see Spider shot in the foot.  79 80 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a set of keys come flying out the window. TILT DOWN TO keys.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Henry is furious. He pushes past Karen and looks out window.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I gotta go out!

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Not tonight, you're not. Not without the car keys, you're not.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Are you nuts?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I don't care. Something's going on.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (exasperated) That again.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (shrieking and in tears) You're a liar. I look at you and I know you're a liar. We see Henry pick up a large lamp and throw it at Karen. He misses.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
