dialogues.text: (suddenly calm and walking out) I need some air. I need a Little peace. At least at home. We see Karen sit down on bed and begin to cry. We hear the CHILDREN CRYING in background.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: with bandaged foot, and Henry walking in, and TILT UP TO both of them. James, Tommy and some hoods are playing cards. Tommy is already drunk. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Hey! Look at this. Fred Astaire, back from the wars. Can you believe this guy? That bandage. It's bigger than his foot. Spider ignores him. The card game is going on. Shirts are unbuttoned. The table filled with empty glasses.. Spider limps over with drinks.

dialogues.speaker: . TOMMY
dialogues.text: Spider. You're so full of shit. Even with that food, I bet you can dance. Spider puts the drinks down and tries to ignore Tommy again.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Come on, Spider. Come on. Let's see you dance.

dialogues.speaker: SPIDER
dialogues.text: Why don't you go fuck yourself.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (laughing) Hey, Spider. That's very good. Did you hear Spider? The kid's got balls. See, the kid's got balls. He's a good kid. Spider starts to limp proudly back to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (whispering to Tommy) You going to take that shit from this punk? This fuckin' lowlife. This kid's got bigger balls than you'll have any day. He just got shot in the foot by you and he tells you to go fuck yourself. I can't believe this shit. (to the crew, roaring with laughter) Can you believe this shit? (to Tommy, almost whispering) Tommy! You gonna take that shit from a punk? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The players are all laughing loudly. Spider is proudly standing near the bar. And, before anyone has any idea of what is about to happen, Tommy pulls out one of his two GUNS and puts THREE DEAFENING SHOTS into Spider's chest. Everyone is frozen in silence. Henry is upset by shooting. There is a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: All right, you dumb fuck, if you're going to be a big fuckin’ wiseguy, you can dig the hole. We see a frowning Tommy get up from table and slowly begin moving chairs around to get ready to dig the hole.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: After Billy Batts and Spider, everything was going crazy. Not just our crew, but everybody. ~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Janice in the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE'S DOOR
dialogues.text: We see Karen pressing the buzzer while holding two hysterical children.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (screaming) Open up! I know you're there! You stay away from my husband.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: She wouldn't open the door. I rang her bell. Still, she wouldn't open. I rang her bell for two hours, and she kept on hiding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA is LOOKING AT him. Feel a presence on top of him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We hear a CLICK. Henry's eyes open. Henry looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the gun aiming right THROUGH the LENS. We can see the bullets in the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (straddling Henry in bed, holding a gun) Henry. (pulls back the hammer) Wake up.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (always deny) What's the matter with you? You're erazy.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (hysterically) Crazy? I'm ‘crazy enough to shoot you and her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen sweating, Henry's profile, the hammer of the gun, etc.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But still I couldn't hurt him. How could I hurt him? I couldn't even bring myself to leave him.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: sweating.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: {carefully moving his head away from the gun) It's all bullshit. I swear. It's nothing. Whatever you want, we'll do.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: io 83 rm 63.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The truth was, that no matter how bad I felt, I was still very attracted to him. Why should I give him up to someone else? Why should she win?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (quickly moving his head away and grabbing the gun) Son of a bitch. We see Henry slap Karen across the face and knock her off the bed.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (angrily getting out of bed and packing his clothes) I don't need this bulishit. I got enough to worry about getting whacked on the street. I gotta come home to get whacked? We see Karen crying.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I swear on my mother, I should kill you. You're fucking crazy. We see Henry hit her. He is about to hit her again, but stops. He turns his back on her and opens the door of his closet roughly grabbing some clothes as if getting ready to pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry opens the door and Paul Cicero and James enter. They walk toward the kitchen. The place is in disarray.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (to Janice) Honey. Go get me some cigarettes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oo 84

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Janice leaves without saying a word.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: (after watching the door close) Karen's come to the house. She's very upset. It's no goed. You gotta straighten this all out. Henry looks down.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Things gotta be calm right now, and Karen's so high-strung. She's with Mickey every day. Who knows what she's gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: James and Tommy were supposed to pick up something in Tampa for me this weekend. James nods in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You go with James, instead, Get away for a few days. Relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see MAN's bleeding face being punched.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Enjoy yourselves. Have a good time. Then, when you get back Monday, you go home to Karen. We PULL BACK to see James and Henry beating a Man who is squashed between them.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (pleading) I ain't got it. I swear. We see James and Henry beat him more.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (crying) I can't. I swear. We see James and Henry look at each other.  85 86 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the ROAR of LIONS. We see James and Henry drag the bookie out of the car by his arms and legs just outside the zoo.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We're gonna feed the bastard to the lions.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (while dragging bookie) What lions? I'm not going near any lions.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We only have to shove'’m over the moat. We see the Man finally begin to squirm and scream.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: on phone with James and Henry waiting outside.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They must really feed each other to the lions down there, because the guy gave the money right up and we got to spend the rest of the weekend at the track. (pause and genuine shock) But then, I couldn't believe what happened.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER PICTURE
dialogues.text: of Henry and James getting arrested.

dialogues.speaker: , HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: When we got home, we were all over the newspapers. At first, I didn't even know why we got picked up.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER PHOTO
dialogues.text: of man they beat being arrested with his head bandaged.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then, I found out, that the guy we roughed up turned out to have a sister working as a typist for the F.B.I.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNMENT OFFICE
dialogues.text: where sobbing typist is surrounded by men in business suits. :

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Who could believe it? Of all the fucking people. She gave up everybody. James. Me. Even her brother. : cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry and James before judge. Karen and children crying in court: Other family members present and crying.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It took the jury six hours to bring us in guilty. The judge gave James and me ten years like he was giving away candy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy, Morris Kessler, Joe Manri, Stacks Edwards, Frenchy McMahon, etc., are all having drinks with Henry before he goes off to prison. We see by the bar clock that it is four o'clock. Suddenly, Karen comes charging into the bar. She is angry. She has tracked Henry down.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (frantic) I thought you were supposed to turn yourself in at ten o'clock this morning?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'm just having my last few drinks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I've been all over town. I got a call from the bondsman. He says they're going to rescind your bail if you don't show up and sign in right now. They're going to take away the house.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Shit. Henry looks at his pals, orders his last Screaming Eagle for a while, and gently touches the tips of Karen's fingers. He swallows his drink, hugs and kisses a tearful Karen and walks out of the bar to a long, white stretch limo waiting at the curb.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Say hello to James. Henry gets in the rear seat of the limo.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (downing a palm full of Valium) Okay, now you can take me to jail.

dialogues.speaker: GARLIC
dialogues.text: being sliced razor thin.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Dinner was always a big thing. We had a pasta course and then meat or fish. Paulie did the prep work. He was doing a year for contempt and he had a system for doing garlic. He used a razor and he sliced it so thin it used to liquify in the pan with a little oil.

dialogues.speaker: HOT PLATE
dialogues.text: with a pot full of tomato sauce and meatballs being stirred. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wont, 89 68.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Vinnie was in charge of the tomato sauce. I felt he put in too many onions, but it was a good sauce anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with smoking steaks.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Johnny Dio did the meat. We didn't have a broiler, so Johnny did everything in pans. He smelled up the joint something awful and the hacks used to die.

dialogues.speaker: HOT PLATE
dialogues.text: hooked up by long extension cord to an electric outlet in the toilet. There are huge kitchen knives, a block of ice in a tin pail covered with a cloth and large pots and colanders necessary for cooking pasta dishes. PULL BACK TO a large dorm with four beds separated by shoulder-height partitions. The room does not look like a prison. There are curtains over the bars. The room is filled with smoke from the pan-fried steak.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Everybody else in the joint was doing real time, all mixed together, living like pigs.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: in grey prison garb, carrying a heavy canvas mail sack marked "LEWISBURG PRISON.” He dumps the sacks on one of the beds. -

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We lived alone. We owned the joint. Even those hacks who we couldn't bribe would never rat on the guys who did.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: opens the sack on his bed and pulls out bottles of wine, Scotch, and brandy, and holds them aloft.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (looking for praise) Nice? Good?

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: (looking up from his garlic surgery) Okay. What else? We see Henry reach in the sack and pull out cheeses, dried sausages, a large jar of vinegar peppers and dried mushrooms.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: (beaming with pride) Now we eat.
We see Henry begin to set the table.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO AND REST OF MOB BOSSES
dialogues.text: playing cards, and sipping wine, Scotch and brandy. Henry is sitting on his bed with his back to the group. When he sees that no one is watching him, he pulis a black plastic garbage bag out of the sack. Henry opens the bag and quickly counts the clear plastic bags of marijuana, glassine envelopes of heroin and bottles of pills. Henry quickly repacks the drugs and slips them under his covers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visiting day. Henry is in a guard's booth watching the visitors' gate through a window. We see a GUARD in the room with Henry. There is a KNOCK. The Guard opens the door and looks at Henry. Henry nods. The Guard lets the inmate enter. While the Guard watches, the inmate gives Henry some cash and Henry gives him one of the plastic bags filled with marijuana and a bottle of pills. The inmate is then escorted out by the Guard who closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Are there any more? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (looking intently at the visiting gate) No, that's it. No more today. We see Henry casually stuff some bills into the Guard's shirt pocket. Cur TO: INT. VISITORS’ GATE - ANGLE ON KAREN - DAY 91 coming through. She is wearing such a large, oversized | coat that Karen looks twice as big as she was when we last saw her. . She has the two children with her. She is carrying a large purse and some empty shopping bags. The guards see her and immediately help her get through the metal detection device and past the table where other women are emptying the contents of their bags and packages. cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: REGISTRATION DESK
dialogues.text: where Karen quickly signs the visitors’ book. cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: GUARD'S GRINNING FACE
dialogues.text: We see him turn page of book so Karen can see the name of another of Henry's visitors.

dialogues.speaker: PAGE OF BOOK
dialogues.text: We see name, "Janice Rossi" written next to HILL, HENRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN BACK TO a large gymnasium filled with formica tables and cheap plastic chairs at which we see prisoners and their wives and children eating, talking, crying and, in discreet corners -- hidden behind makeshift screens of shopping bags and scarves -- having oral sex. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We see that the bored guards are indifferent to what is happening.

dialogues.speaker: TABLE
dialogues.text: Henry and Karen are talking while we see the children playing in the distance at the commissary food machines.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (fuming) You son of a bitch. She's been here. -

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (acting dumb) What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (gottcha) Don't lie to me. I saw her name in the register.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Jezuz Christ!

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You want her to visit you? Good! . Let her stay up all night crying and writing letters to the parole board.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (astounded) What am I doing? I'm in here! I'm in jail. I can't stop people from coming to see me. We see Karen open her coat revealing large inside pockets where she has stowed salamis, wine, cigarettes, cartons etc.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You want her? Good! Let her sneak this stuff in for you. We see Karen slam a salami on the table with such a thud that the other prisoners and wives turn around.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Let her fight with these creep bastards every week to make life easier for you! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We see Karen slam down cigarettes and wine with a thud, this time we see a guard turn around and look at Karen and Henry and the contraband on the table. Pause. We see the guard turn his head away.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (desperate) Stop! - Stop!

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Let her carry this. shit inside. We see Karen boldly wave a baggie filled with marijuana and some plastic medicine containers with pills. Henry grab the narcotics out of Karen's hand and grabs her. We see Henry hug Karen to him and we see her drop her arms and hug him.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (quietly sobbing) Nobody's helping me. Tommy got four years. Morris and Belle are broke. I asked your friend Remo for the money he owed you, and you know what he told me?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (stroking her head and soothing her) It'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: He told me to take the kids to the police station and make the cops put me on welfare. We see Henry take the drugs from Karen's hand and slip it into his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We've got to help each other.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Even Paulie, since he got out, I hardly see him.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It's only you and me. That's what happens when you go away. We're on our own. Forget. everybody. Forget Paulie. As Iong as he's on parole he doesn't want anybody doing anything. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (sobbing) I can't do it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yes, you can. I've got it set up. We'll be fine. All I need is for you to keep bringing the stuff. I've got a guy in here from Pittsburgh who'll move it for me. Believe me, in a month we'll be fine. We won't need anybody.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I'm afraid. I'm afraid if Paulie finds out.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Don't worry about Paulie. Is he helping you? Is he putting food on the table? We've got to help ourselves. We just have to be careful while we do it.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (looking in his face) I don't want to hear about her anymore.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (hugging her to him) Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry comes out in civilian clothes. We see his face drop. PAN OVER to the beat-up old car. Karen is behind the wheel. Henry gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The signs of wealth are long gone. Henry sees that Karen has been living four tough, lean years. Their daughters are watching as Henry looks around the house. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (smiling faintly) Get packed. We're getting out of here.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: With what?

dialogues.speaker: , HENRY
dialogues.text: (smiling, slyly) Don't worry with what. You just start looking for a new place. I'm going to Pittsburgh in the morning. The guys from Pittsburgh they owe me fifteen grand from our little partnership and it's only the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: But you've got to see your parole officer in the afternoon and... (whispering) I promised we'd take Lois to F.A.O. Schwarz.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. You listening to me? Now, come on. We gotta go see Paulie.

dialogues.speaker: PLATTERS OF FOOD
dialogues.text: coming out of the kitchen and placed on the table.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO AND HENRY
dialogues.text: walking toward the edge of the dock.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: I don't want any more of that shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wha? Me? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: Just stay away from the garbage. You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (shocked) Me? Why would I get into that shit?

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I know what you did inside. You . did what you had to do. I'm not. talking about that. I'm talking from now on, outside. I'm talking right here.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Why would I get into that?

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: Don't make me a fool. You know what I mean. From now on, you gotta be careful. Just don't mess around with that shit, and watch out for James. James' a good earner, but he's sometimes too hungry. He's wild. He does foolish things. James is not a businessman. As good as he is, he takes too many chances.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I know that. I know James. You think I'd take chances like James?

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: And that Tommy. He's a good kid, but he's crazy. He's a cowboy. He's got too much to prove. You got to watch out for kids like that.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Paulie, I know. I know what they are. But I use them for certain things. Please. Believe me, you don't have to worry. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: (not even listening to Henry's protest) I'm not going to get fucked like Gribbs. He's seventy years old and the fucking guy is going to die in prison. I don't need that. I don't care who it is. I'm warning everybody. Gribbs got twenty years just because he said hello to some fuck who was sneaking around selling junk behind his. back. That's not going to happen to me. You understand?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Paulie. Why would I? I swear.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: You're only home early because we got you a job, right? And I don't need any heat. You understand? Henry nods.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: And, if you hear about anybody else fucking around with that shit, you tell me. Henry nods again.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: (gently slapping Henry on the cheek) Anybody! You understand?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: mixing coke in metal bowl. We see Henry standing behind her. Sandy is an intense, sexy, 30-year-old, divorced, ex-airport clerk. (Sandy is described earlier in Scene #75, page 57, where. she flirts with Henry.) The apart- ment is a jumbled mess and even the table where she is cutting the drugs is littered with old coffee cups, newspapers, and day-old dirty dishes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It took me about a week of sneaking around before I could unload the Pittsburgh stuff without Paulie finding out. But when I did, it was a real score. I started using Sandy's place ‘to mix the stuff-and-even with Sandy's snorting more than she mixed, I could see this was a good business. I made twelve thousand dollars in my second week and I had a down payment on my house. All I had to do was every once in a while, tell Sandy I loved her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where stubby pencil calculations are being scribbled.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was perfect. As long as I kept getting the stuff from Pittsburgh, I knew Paulie would never find out. But within a couple of weeks it got to be so big I needed help. I got James and Tommy to come in with me.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.5.)
dialogues.text: Fifteen, sixteen, eighteen, twenty-one-five.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: opening a shoe box he has hidden in a plastic grocery bag. James and Tommy lean close to Henry in order to see inside.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (smiling) Did I tell you?

dialogues.speaker: OPEN SHOE BOX
dialogues.text: filled with twenty dollar bills. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAMES, (0.5S.)
dialogues.text: Nice. :

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who's buying? We see Henry's thumb run through the tightly-stacked twenties like piano keys.

dialogues.speaker: PAROLE OFFICER
dialogues.text: in tired business suit coming out of door, over which we see sign reading "UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE - PAROLE DIVISION"... And we see that Henry, James and Tommy are in the large brightly-lit parole office counting their drug profits.

dialogues.speaker: PAROLE OFFICER
dialogues.text: (overworked and looking around the crowded waiting room) Conway? We see James and PAROLE OFFICER walk into the office.

dialogues.speaker: PAROLE OFFICER
dialogues.text: Still working? Door closes.

dialogues.speaker: WHOLE FLOOR
dialogues.text: filled with ex-con parolees. cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Morris Kessler and his wife, Belle, being taken on tour of an over-decorated and expensive living room. (NOTE: Shot almost like a commercial.)

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: This we had to have made special. I mean, sit in it. Go ahead. Sit. Belle plops onto sofa. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (0.5.)
dialogues.text: The others you couldn't even sit in. And from here, watch the wall. Karen's hand flicks a switch on table next to sofa, and wall slides back, revealing TV and stereo.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: See. It opens. We had the electricians fix it up special. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: This we imported. It came in two pieces. ON third object, PAN TO Karen. As Karen and Belle Kessler disappear behind swinging kitchen doors, Morris and Henry drop onto the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: It's a fait accompli?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: And James's in it, right?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Will you stop?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: But you don't understand. It's worth millions. It's once in a lifetime. We'll be rich. No more nut every week. I've been cultivating this thing for two years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a seedy mob hangout. We see all of the wiseguys who will be a part of the Lufthansa robbery. Morris, Henry, Tommy, and James are watching a basketbail game.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And these are the guys.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY AND FRANKY CARBONE
dialogues.text: who are leaning with their backs against the bar, their jackets open, bosses of all they survey.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Tommy and Carbone were going to grab the outside guard and make him get us in the front door.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: FRENCHY McMAHON who is playing shuffleball.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Frenchy and -- cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: JOE BUDDHA
dialogues.text: sprinkling sawdust on the shuffleboard table.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Joe Buddha had to round up the workers. CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: FAT LOUIE
dialogues.text: who is about 300 pounds and is sitting backwards in a chair, watching the TELEVISION with a drink in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Fat Louis had to keep them tied up and away from alarms.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: shoving his way between James and Henry at the bar and turning to the television basketball game. HENRY (V.0.). Only Morris was driving us nuts. He was busting James's balls for an advance on the money we were going to steal.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STACKS EDWARDS
dialogues.text: who is sitting at the bar, delicately stirring his drink with his pinky.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Even Stacks got in on it. He was supposed to steal the panel truck and afterwards compact it by a friend of ours in Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: BABY
dialogues.text: LOIS BYRD, a young, pale blonde woman, puts the baby and an overnight bag on the bed as Henry and Karen watch.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I had everybody working. Even our old babysitter.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (enthused) She's beautiful. Look at her. Henry, look at her.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (singsong) Hello! Hello! (to Lois) Have a good flight?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: I hate Pittsburgh. We see Lois Byrd unwrap the baby's pink snowsuit and take off its hood and mittens as Henry opens Lois's overnight bag and takes out some Pampers and then he takes out several plastic bags with cocaine and heroin.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Where'd you find such creeps?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: They're okay and it's worth it. Ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (playing with the baby) Is this the same one as last time? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: (amazed that Karen can't tell the difference) No. That one was my sister's. This is Louise's.

dialogues.speaker: KARNE
dialogues.text: Look at her, Henry, is she sweet? Doesn't she look like Lois?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: That's what the stewardess said. We see Henry barely listening while putting the drugs in a@ paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: COKEBALLS 101
dialogues.text: COME BACK to see Henry at table making “"cokeballs" in a metal press.

dialogues.speaker: LINE OF COKE ON MIRROR
dialogues.text: shoved under Henry's nostril. We see straw inserted into Henry's nostril as he casually inhales. He never stops pressing the cokeballs. TRACK OUT TO Sandy taking a snort herself, and the sloppy table with the drugs, scales, mixers, bowls and sieves. Sandy is razor-blading two more lines.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (watching out of the corner of his eye) Hey! Watch out. We see Sandy lick her finger and then run her finger across Henry's tongue. He licks, but does not react as he takes several golfball-size cokeballs out of the machine and puts them in a leather pouch. He gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Stay there. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: —_e we we 101

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Don't start. I told you to clean up. Look at this place. It's a pigpen. Look around here. Why do you think I bought you the dishwasher? Look. Look at this. (sticking his finger under ‘Sandy's nose) There's enough powder around here to put us all away.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: (licking Henry's finger and playfully pushing him into the chair) I hate to do dishes.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (sitting down again) Hey, come on. I gotta meet somebody.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: (reaching over his shoulder toward his crotch) So do I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Henry look at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry is listening to the RADIO while taking his SHOWER.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO NEWS BROADCASTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .».. and nobody knows for sure just how much was taken in the daring pre-dawn raid at the Lufthansa cargo terminal at Kennedy Airport. The F.B.I. says two million dollars, Port Authority police say four million dollars, the city cops say five. How much maximum? That they won't say. So far, Lufthansa has not said anything, but they've promised to break their silence soon with a press conference, and W.1I.N.S. will be there to cover it live from the scene of the heist at J.F.K. when they do. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 102 oe 103 aa

dialogues.speaker: RADIO NEWS BROADCASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It looks like a big one. Maybe the biggest this town has ever seen. Stay tuned... Henry slams the soap onto the shower floor and pounds the wall with joy.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Are you okay? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Nothing. I dropped the soap. That's all. EXT. ROBERT'S LOUNGE - NIGHT ‘ 103 Private Christmas party. As they arrive, Henry and Karen are hugged by James in the doorway. It is a Lufthansa victory party, but no one mentions the robbery:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (grabbing Henry around the neck and kissing his head) Come here. (to Karen) Look at this genius. James keeps his arms around Henry and Karen as FAT LOUIE CAFORA shows up with his new wife, Dolores, who is also over 200 pounds. They are beaming with pride.

dialogues.speaker: FAT LOUIE
dialogues.text: (to James and Henry.) Come outside. I gotta show you. Just for a minute. We see a new pink Caddy convertible. The sticker is still in the window.

dialogues.speaker: FAT LOUIE, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Is that beautiful? I got it for Dolores.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (whispering angrily at Fat Louie) You fucking nuts? Didn't I say not to go buy anything for a while. You got a fucking car? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FAT LOUIE
dialogues.text: (trying to placate James as he enters the bar) Don't get excited. It's okay. My mother bought it for us. It's a wedding present. It's in her name.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You're crazy. The bulls are across the street. They're watching everything we do. CUT TO:.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops in front.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: as he watches Fat Louie walk into the bar.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (angrily whispering to Henry) The fat fuck ought to wear a sign. We see a smiling Franky Carbone walk in the door and we see that his WIFE is wearing a $30,000 sable coat.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! Are you all fucking nuts?

dialogues.speaker: CARBONE
dialogues.text: (to Henry) What's the matter with him? Before Henry can answer, we see James start to grab the coat off MRS. CARBONE'S back.

dialogues.speaker: CARBONE
dialogues.text: Hey? What the fuck are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CARBONE
dialogues.text: (hysteria rising) Franky! He's taking my coat! Franky! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, we see James grabbing the coat off Mrs. Cabone's back and begin to roll it up and shove it under Carbone's arm.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (furiously, to Carbone) Didn't I tell you not to get anything big? Didn't I tell you not to attract attention? In two days, one fuck buys a Caddy and another buys a.ten thousand dollar mink. (to Henry} Can you believe this shit? (to Carbone, with Some menace) Now get the fuck home and get rid ef the coat. Bring it back to where you got it. I don't care what you do, just get rid of it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CARBONE
dialogues.text: (to Carbone, hysterical and angry) I'm not giving it back. Franky? Do you hear me? We see Carbone angrily grab his wife's arm and leave.

dialogues.speaker: CARBONE
dialogues.text: Did I tell you to shut up? Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (to Henry, as they walk toward the bar) Fucking guys. Can you believe them. I told them all: Don't attract attention. Act normal. At the bar, we see Stacks Edwards and his girlfriend drop ping shot glasses of green creme de menthe into large glasses of chilled Dom Perignon. Tommy and his girl-for- the-night are standing with Stacks and his girlfriend. Tommy is wearing a shiny silk suit that practically glows with newness. We see Frenchy and Buddha with their wives. Everyone is dressed in new clothes and flashing gaudy rings. James and Henry move toward a quiet corner of the bar. We see Morris Kessler suddenly burst in on them.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Oh! There you are. I've been looking all over for you two.’ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Henry and James stare at Morris, blankly.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Listen. I need it, James. I need it all. James gets up to walk away without even looking at Morris

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Morris, relax. You saw some money.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: (continues anyway) But I need it all. I owe people, too, you know. . We see James walk toward small office in the back of the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James. Wait. Listen. Please. We see that Morris is about to follow James into the room but Henry stops him.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: I wanna talk to James.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He heard.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: But I got two hundred and fifty coming. It's my share. James owes me.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (following James into the backroom) Morris, please. Let me talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: BACKROOM
dialogues.text: James and Henry are alone. We see James take a thick stack of bills from inside his jacket pocket and press them into Henry's chest.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: For Christmas. Your share. It's just a taste. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: James.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (embracing Henry) We did it. We did it. We hear a KNOCK on the door. James stops as if caught.

dialogues.speaker: MALE, (0.5.)
dialogues.text: Hey, James. James. James returns to normal.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah. I'll be right there. CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: TREE
dialogues.text: We see Henry coming in with the tree.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Hey! Look what I got. The most expensive tree they had.

dialogues.speaker: HUGE WHITE TREE
dialogues.text: all set up with large purple balis. We see Karen and the children excited by the presents revealed under the tree. We see Karen kiss Henry, who slips a thick packet of bills into the front of her dress.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Go buy yourself a coat. Karen shivers with excitement. CAMERA DOLLIES INTO tree.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Lufthansa should have been our ultimate.score. The heist of a lifetime. Six million in cash. More than enough to go around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacks in bed. We hear a loud KNOCKING at the door.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (0.5S.)
dialogues.text: Hey! Stacks! Come on! Open the door! Wake up!

dialogues.speaker: STACKS
dialogues.text: opening the door.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKY
dialogues.text: You got coffee?

dialogues.speaker: STACKS
dialogues.text: Fucks! You said you had coffee.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (to Franky) Put on a pot.

dialogues.speaker: STACKS
dialogues.text: (putting on his trousers) Ball-busting sons of bitches. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: STACKS
dialogues.text: bending over to put on his shoes. We hear WATER in the sink. CuT To:

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: pulling out a .38 caliber gun with a silencer from his belt.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Stacks was always crazy. Instead of getting rid of the truck like he was supposed to, he got stoned, went to his girlfriend's and by the time he woke up, the cops had found the truck. It was all over the television. They even said they came up with prints off the wheel. It was just a matter of time before they got to Stacks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: En 108° INT. HENRE'S HOUSE - wicer 7 108 We hear. a DOORBELL; waking ‘Henry. and | Karen from slee ~~ : WOMAN (0.8. ). : . Open up: ~.-Henry! “Karen! It's me. Belle! : (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: In twenty years he's never been away all night without calling. I know something's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Awright, awright. Let me take you home and I'11 go look for him myself. Right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry and James are leaving together.

dialogues.speaker: . HENRY
dialogues.text: What'1ll I tell Belle?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Who gives a fuck? Tell her he ran away with a broad. What do you care about her. Suddenly James spots two FBI men who had been tailing him, dozing in their unmarked car. He starts toward their car.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Watch this.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Come on, don't fuck around, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I do it all the time. Bust their fucking balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James... Come on. Fuck ‘em. Don't give them the satisfaction. Henry watches James tiptoe up to the Agents’ car and rap on the window. The startled agents look and see James staring at them.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Come on, fuckoes. Let's go for a ride. (to Henry as James starts his car) I keep ‘em up all fucking night. While Henry walks to his own car, we see James ROAR off and we hear the SQUEAL of TIRES and brakes as James and still sleepy agents in pursuit speed away from the club.  110 111 112 95.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR SCHOOL BUS STOP
dialogues.text: We see some youngsters walk over to peek in the car. The youngsters are giggling. One boy sneaks up alongside the car door and peeks inside. We hear a yell. We see the bodies of Fat Louie Cafora and his wife, Dolores, slumped against each other on the front seat. Blood has caked all over their faces from small bullet holes in their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see large garbage truck back up to the dumpster as garbage man lashes two steel cables to rings on top of dumpster. We see garbage man signal for 0.S. to tighten cable and tip dumpster into truck.

dialogues.speaker: TOP OF DUMPSTER
dialogues.text: as it is tipped over and we see an arm fall over the side and as dumpster tips more we see another arm and the dead faces of Frenchy McMahon and Joe Buddha as garbage man screams to helper 0.5. to stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the open door of a large refrigeration truck. We see bright lights and flashbulbs go off. CAMERA STEADILY MOVES IN ON frozen body hanging from a rack inside the truck.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: James was cutting every link between himself and the robbery, but it had nothing to do with me. I gave James the tip and he gave me some Christmas money. From then on I kept my mouth shut. I knew James. He had the cash. It was his. I know he kicked some money upstairs to Paulie, but that was it. It made him sick to have to turn money over to the guys who stole it. He'd rather whack them. Anyway, what did I care? I wasn't asking for anything and, besides, James was making nice money with me through my Pittsburgh connections. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But still, for months after the robbery, they were finding bodies all over. CAMERAS MOVES ONTO a CLOSEUP of Franky Carbone's frozen face.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: When they found Carbone in the meat truck, he was frozen so stiff it took them two days to thaw him out for the autopsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bright sunny afternoon, Henry and James seated in a window booth. We see James eating eggs on pancakes with Sausages and toasted English muffins.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Still, I never saw James so happy. He was like a kid. We had money coming in through my Pittsburgh people and after a while even the Lufthansa thing began to calm down. But the thing that made James so happy that morning was that this was the day Tommy was being made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Tommy is all dressed. He kisses his mother. Tommy walks down the stairs toward two wiseguys and into a waiting. car.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: James was so excited, you'd think he was being made. He must have made four calls to Tommy's house. They had a signal all set up so he'd know the minute the ceremony was over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James has finished his breakfast and spots Henry's untouched melon.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (looking at watch) You want the melon? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Nah.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (reaches for the melon and looks at his watch) I-better call again.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: James and I could never be made, because we had Irish blood. It didn't even matter that my mother. was Sicilian. To become a member of the crew, you've got to be one hundred percent Italian so that they can trace all your relatives back to the old country.

dialogues.speaker: FLOOR
dialogues.text: We see the car pull into basement garage and door close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In window, we see James cross the parking lot to an out- door phone booth on the side of the road. TRUCKS are ROARING past.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It's the highest honor they can give you. It means you belong to a family and a crew. It means that nobody can fuck around with you. It also means you can fuck around with anybody, as long as they aren't also a member. It's like a license to steal. INT. BASEMENT ROOM OFF GARAGE 118 . As Tommy proudly walks into the room, followed by the two wiseguys.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: As far as James was concerned, with Tommy being made, it was like we were all being made. We would now have one of our own guys as a member. Tommy proudly walks into the room. We see a hood sud- denly appear behind him, put a GUN to his head and FIRE. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We see Tommy inertly drop to the ground in a heap.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Except, they didn't make Tommy that day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, James slams down the phone with so much strengt that the booth sudders.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They killed him. It was revenge for Billy Batts. When James turns around, we see that he is crying. We see Henry hurrying toward James to console him.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And there was nothing we could do. Batts was a made man and Tommy wasn't. We had to sit still and take it. It was among the Italians. It was real greaseball shit. They even shot Tommy in the face so his mother couldn't give him an open coffin at the funeral. COME UP ON DATE -- SUNDAY, JANUARY 11, 1979. TITLE UP -- 6:55 AM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Henry putting a paper bag filled with guns into the trunk of his car. We hear the loud noise of a HELICOPTER. We see Henry look up. We see a red heli- copter. Henry slams the trunk closed. We hear the HELICOPTER.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I was going to be busy all day. I had to drop off some thirty- eights at James's to match some silencers he had gotten. I had to pick up my brother at the hospital and drive him back to the house for dinner and then I had to pick up some new Pittsburgh stuff for Lois to fly down to some customers I had near Atlanta.  120 121 122 123 99.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY'S FACE 120
dialogues.text: As he drives he sees the helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry full face, car in b.g. We see James grab one of the guns in his doorway and try to screw on a silencer he had in his pocket. He can't.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: What fucking good are these things? They don't fit. What do I need this for? I'm not paying for this shit.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Right ‘away I knew he didn't want them. I knew I was going to get stuck for the money. I only bought the damn guns because he wanted them. And now, he didn't want them. I didn't say a thing. James was so pissed he didn't even say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: putting torn bag with guns back into car trunk. TITLE UP - 8:05 AM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Henry speeding toward top of a rise in highway approaching Queens Midtown Tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I knew my Pittsburgh guys always wanted guns, and since I was going to see them later in the afternoon to pick up a delivery, I was pretty sure I'd get my money back. Henry looks up and sees the red helicopter. When he looks back at the road he is suddenly confronted with a huge traffic jam spread out before him. We see him jam his foot.on the brakes. TITLE UP - 8:45 AM.  124 125 126 100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bedraggled Henry arrives in his brother Michael's room. Michael is all dressed and sitting in his wheelchair, waiting to go.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: When I finally got there to pick up Michael, his doctor wanted-to -put me in bed. I told him about the accident. I said I was partying all night.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He took mercy on me. He gave me ten milligrams of Valium and sent me home. My plan was to drop off my brother at the house and pick up Karen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Henry driving Michael. Henry looks up and sees the red helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (to Michael) I think that helicopter's following me.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Are you nuts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Michael, in his wheelchair, chopping celery. We see Henry making meatballs. Lois Byrd is also there, helping Karen shell peas. Lois's overnight bag is on the kitchen table, surrounded by food. The children are play- ing on the kitchen floor.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I was cooking dinner that night. I had to start braising the beef, pork butt and veal shanks for the tomato sauce. It's Michael's favorite. I was making ziti and the meat gravy, and I'm planning to roast some peppers over the flames, and I was putting on some string beans with the olive oil and garlic, and I had some beautiful cutlets, cut just right, that I was going to fry up before dinner just as an appetizer. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I was home for about an hour. My plan was to start the dinner early, so Karen and I could go unload the guns that James didn’t want, and get the package for Lois to take to Atlanta later that night. I kept looking out the window and the helicopter was gone. I asked Michael to watch the sauce, and Karen and I started out. TITLE UP - 11:30 AM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see.Karen and Henry in car when Karen points out the window.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We're going to your mother's.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Now I'm sure we're being tailed. My plan was to go to her mother's and unload the guns. Who needed them in the trunk with all this heat?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: putting the guns into garbage cans.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (to Karen) Go inside. Tell her not to touch anything outside the house. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAREN AND HENRY
dialogues.text: Looking up at helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Let's go shopping.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE
dialogues.text: Nearby we see Karen standing outside of their parked car. In b.g., we see a large, busy shopping mall with cars and shoppers. TITLE UP - 12:30 PM.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I'm not nuts. It's been following me all fucking morning. I mean it. We see Henry slam down the phone. DOLLY INTO face.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (to Karen) They think I'm paranoid. The dumb fucks. I should bring them the helicopter, then we'll see how paranoid I am. TITLE UP - 1:30 PM.

dialogues.speaker: MALL ENTRY
dialogues.text: Henry and Karen peek out the mall deor surrounded by people with shopping carts and look into the sky for the helicopter. It is gone. He listens. No noise. HENRY . Okay! Quick! Let’s get back to your mother's.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: getting guns out of garbage. TITLE UP - 3:30 PM.  103.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Pittsburgh DEALER laughing as Henry gives him the package of guns. A young man is also standing in the room.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: Didn't I tell you you were paranoid? See, Karen, didn't I-tell him he was paranoid?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: {barely looking up and wandering toward kitchen) I need some coffee. Dealer puts his arm around Henry and motions him toward the bedroom where they snort some coke and laugh. After snorting the coke, we see the Dealer give Henry a plastic package of heroin he has taken out of a paper bag on the dresser. Henry casually puts it in his jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My plan was I had to get home and get the package ready for Leis to take on her trip. Also, (o~ I had to get to Sandy's house to . give the package a whack with some quinine. Plus, I knew Sandy was gonna get on my ass. Then I had the cooking to finish at home, and I had to get Lois ready for the trip. PHONE RINGS in bedroom. Dealer picks it up, listens a moment and offers it to Henry.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: (whispering so Karen cannot hear in next room) It's Sandy

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Yeah. Henry covers the mouthpiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dealer) A pain in the ass. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) I'll see you in about an hour. (pause) I can't. I got my brother home tonight. (pause) We'll talk about it later. Okay? Henry hangs up the phone, pauses and dials again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHONE RINGS. We see Lois Byrd answer the phone. We see Michael is stirring the tomato sauce.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Henry is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You ready? CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Tell Michael not to let the sauce stick. cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: (to Michael, who is still stirring) Henry says don't let the sauce Stick.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I'm stirring. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: \ HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (on phone) You know what to do?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: (bored) Yeah, yeah. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Now this is important. Make sure you leave the house when you make the call. You understand? Do you hear me? It's important. Call from an outside phone. I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Jesus! You must think I'm dumb. (o What are you bugging me for? : I know what to do!

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0)
dialogues.text: Just make sure you do it. You know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! You can be such @ pain.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Just do what I say!

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Okay. We see Lois hang up the kitchen wall phone.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (still stirring) What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Nothing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lois Byrd takes a puff on her cigarette and starts to fish around in the bottom of her pocketbook which is on the kitchen counter near the wall phone. We see Lois Byrd take out the airline ticket.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So, what does she do after she hangs up with me? After everything I had told her? After all her yeah, yeah, yeah, bullshit? She picks up the phone and calls from the house. Now, if anybody was listening, they'd know everything. They'd know that a package was leaving from my house and they'd even have the time and the flight number. Thanks to her. Lois Byrd reaches for the kitchen phone and calls. TITLE UP - 6:30 PM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry is working in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: As soon as I got home, I started cooking. I had a few hours until Lois's flight. I told my brother to keep an eye on the stove. All day long, the poor guy's been watching helicopters and tomato sauce. I had to drive over to Sandy's place, mix it once and get back to the gravy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Henry watching Sandy mix the half-kilo of heroin with milk sugar, doubling the amount. There is silence between them. Henry looks at his watch. Sandy pauses for a moment and sniffs a line of coke she has cut on a mirror near the table. Henry snorts some coke, too. The table and room is a mess. Mixing bowls, scales, and sieves are strewn around the room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: (getting angrier while mixing) I don't need this... You said tonight and now it's not tonight... ‘HENRY (watching the dope being mixed while stroking Sandy's neck and shoulders) It's okay. I'll make it up. I promise. Just hurry it up a little. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: (finishing the package with tape, and almost purring) Okay? We see Henry grab the two half-kilo packages off the table and start for the door. Sandy is startled.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: (shrieking) You bastard! Where are you going? We see Henry get out the door just before Sandy throws the scale at it. TITLE UP - 8:30 PM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After dinner. Everyone is feeling very expansive. Lois and Henry have left the table and are standing in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: (to Henry) I gotta go home.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What for? I got a pound of stuff in my jacket I've been carrying around all day. We gotta start start taping it to your leg.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: I gotta go home and get my hat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Forget your fucking hat. What are you, kidding me? Just what I need now is a trip to Rockaway. Just because you want your hat.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Ioneed it. .I- gotta have it. It's my lucky hat. I never fly without it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Do you realize what we're involved in here now?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: I don't care. I need my hat. I won't go without. it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What could I do? If she insisted, I had to drive her home for her goddamn hat. I threw the package in the kitchen and went to take her home.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: nodding to Karen that the heroin is in the kitchen. TITLE UP - 10:45 PM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Henry and Lois get into his car. As they start to move out of the driveway, Henry notices that there is a traffic jam in front of his property. People are walking around with flashlights. It looks like ‘an accident. Suddenly, a MAN in Windbreaker appears at Henry's window and jams a gun against Henry's head.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: One move, motherfucker, and I'll blow you away.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: For a second 1 thought I was dead, but when I heard all the noise, I knew they were cops. Only cops talk that way. If they had been wiseguys, I wouldn't have heard a thing. I would have been dead.  137 138 139 109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Karen hurriedly flushing heroin down the toilet upstairs while we hear FBI MEN at the door downstairs. We hear Michael and children's voices downstairs. We see Karen go to the bureau drawer and grab a small caliber gun, lift her dress and, grimacing, shove the cold metal into her underpants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry is seated and surrounded by FBI Men and PROSECUTOR EDWARD MCDONALD. We see Lois Byrd brought in past Henry and ushered into another room. We see the Dealer ushered past Henry and placed into yet another room.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: All day I thought the guys in the helicopter were just local cops busting my balls over Lufthansa, but they turned out to be Narks. They had been on me a month. Phone taps. Surveillance. We see Sandy brought in, followed by two cops carrying cardboard boxes filled with pots, sieves and scales from Sandy's table. The cops put the boxes on a table where Henry can see them. We see one of the Narks lick his finger after wiping it across one of the bowls. He smiles at Henry and rolls his eyes. We see Henry slouch further in his seat while questioning continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Karen and Henry seated at a table in a visiting area. Henry is nervously looking around at the guards and whispering to Karen.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (anxious ) James's calling every day. It's urgent.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: {a little annoyed at Karen) What did he say, exactly?  110.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (her turn to be annoyed) At least James and Mickey want to help. I talk to Mickey every day. That's more than I can say for the rest. :

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V..0.)
dialogues.text: (placating) Paul will calm down. You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Mickey on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I told James the cops took our cars and froze our bank accounts and he offered to get me some money. He wants to know what's happening. You gotta meet him:

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Fuck James and the money. Didn't I tell you I gotta get out of here first. I gotta straighten everything out with Paulie or I'm dead. CAMERA PANS to sinister James Conway in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (annoyed and indicating the jail) Then you're safer in here.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Safe? Here? They'll kill me here. They're all afraid I'm gonna rat them out. People are already looking to walk away from me. I'm dead in here. You gotta get me out.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (worried) Who's gonna do that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (pleading) Just get me out. CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Her face drops, but she's not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Henry hurry out of the prison. He looks nervous over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Karen finally got her mother to put her house up for my bail. I was out. We see Karen and her mother are waiting in the car.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I remember I had this feeling I was going to get killed right outside the jail. I knew Paulie was still pissed at me and he's such a hothead I was afraid he might have me whacked before he calmed down. And I was also worried about James. James knew if Paulie found out he was in the drug deals with me, Paulie would have James killed even before me. This is the bad time. I didn't feel safe until I got. home.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: frantically looking around the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So now my plan was to stay alive long enough to sell off the dope that the cops never found and disappear for a while until I got things straightened cut.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (to Karen) Where's the stuff? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You know. The stuff I left.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (beginning to cry) I flushed it down the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (anguish and anger mixed) You what?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (erying anguish) What did you want me to do with it? They were all over the house.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Are you fucking nuts? That was forty, fifty thousand. I need it. I was depending on that money.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (crying) They had a warrant. They went through everything. They would have found it. I swear.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Shit! You know they would have never found it. Why did you do it? Why did you do it? My God, why did you have to do it?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (a primal screen) Oh no! No! WNoooo!

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (screaming) Why? Why? We see Henry and Karen holding onto each other as they ery and scream, with the SCREAMS ECHOING out on the SOUNDTRACK.

dialogues.speaker: THEIR FACES
dialogues.text: asleep, and CAMERA DOLLIES OUT to reveal a gun in Henry's hand as they sleep.  145 113.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is closed, but inside we see Paul Cicero in the kitchen cooking peppers and eggs in a frying pan with olive oil. We see several hoods surrounding him at a distance. Various supplicants, a local butcher, an old lady, etc., wait for a papal audience.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: (looking down) I warned you a million times.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I've been all fucked up since I got out.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: You think I didn't know what you were doing? ‘ HENRY It was easy money. I did it in the can. Shit! I learned the junk business in the can, Paulie.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: Right in my face. You looked in my face and you lied.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But, Paulie, I'm sorry. Believe me. I was fucking crazy. But I'm okay now. I can be trusted. I'm clean now. On my children. Believe me! Two weeks cold turkey waiting for bail got my head together.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: You thought I was some fucking jerk?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Paulie, I couldn't come to you. I didn't want to put you in this shit. (pause) I was ashamed to come to you. I knew I was wrong. We see Cicero stand, mute.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Paulie. You're all I got. I need help. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: You treated me like shit. We see Cicero reach into his pocket and take out a thick wad of bills. Without counting the money he puts the cash in Henry's hands. Cicero clasps Henry's hands in his own.

dialogues.speaker: CICERO
dialogues.text: (looking down while handing Henry the cash) Here. Take it. (looking up with tears in his eyes) Now I gotta turn my back on you.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Thirty-two hundred bucks. That's what he gave me. Thirty-two hundred bucks for a lifetime. It wouldn't have paid for the coffin. cuUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I'm not going to run. Live the rest of our lives like rats. Is that what you want? Leave my mother. Leave my family. Never see anybody again.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (pleading) We're gonna leave then anyway, because if we stay around here we're gonna be dead.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (angrily pulling away They're right. You are paranoid.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: nervously pacing near the doorway. There are jukeboxes and pinball machines of various sizes and hues on the sidewalk. Some are being loaded onto panel trucks and carted off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (concerned) How is he? Okay? Are they busting his chops?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: He's okay. They sobered him up.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Did he say what they're asking him about?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: James. I don't know. I got so much else on my mind. I got the kids. We got no money.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I gotta talk to him as soon as I can.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: He says he's too hot. He doesn't even know I came here today. It's like he's crazy, James.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I know. I know. But it'll be okay. Don't worry. I got some money for you. It's down the block. We see James lead Karen to the edge of the sidewalk and point down the block toward a row of stores.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (pointing) The third store down.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: James just stood there on the Sidewalk. It felt funny. I Started walking down the block, but I noticed the stores were empty.

dialogues.speaker: EMPTY STOREFRONTS
dialogues.text: with chalked windows. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAREN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I got a bad feeling. I just kept walking. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: standing on sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (shouting) Inside! Go in there! cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: EMPTY STOREFRONT
dialogues.text: with open door and dark figures waiting inside.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (very rattled) James, I'm in a hurry. I've got to pick up the kids at my mother's. I'll come back later. We see Karen hurry down the block past the stores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Karen's CAR SCREECH to a halt near the garage as Henry comes racing out of the house toward her. He has a gun pressed close to his side. We see Karen is frozen to the wheel in fear. She is visibly shaking, crying. We see Henry very gently pull her from behind the wheel. He has cradled her in his arms as, after a wary look around the street, Henry walks her toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What happened? You okay?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I got scared.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (soothing) Okay. Don't worry about it. It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: (still in shock) I got scared.  149 117.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES IN ON table.

dialogues.speaker: LONG TRACKING SHOT THROUGH RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: You don't know what you're tracking until you see all the food on the table and James looks up.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: If you're part of a crew, nobody ever tells you that they're going to kill you. It doesn't happen that way. There aren't any arguments or curses like in the movies. Your murderers come with smiles. They come as your friends, the people who have cared for you all your life, and they always come at a time when you are at your. weakest and most in need of their help. So I met James in a crowded place we both knew. I got there fifteen minutes early and I saw that James was already there. He took the booth near the window so he could see everyone who drove up to the restaurant. He wanted to see if I had been tailed. James stands to embrace Henry. We see a table with melon, eggs, sausage, toasted English muffins, etc. Henry notices that James has not touched any of the food. Next to James, we see a large legal folder.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (smiling, friendly greeting) You look good.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) I didn't need the headache.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Come on, eat something.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I can't eat, just get me some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He was jumpy. He hadn't touched a thing. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: In the old days, James would have ordered doubles and eaten it all. On the surface, of course, everything was supposed to be fine. We were supposed to be discussing my case, just like we always would, but I had a feeling James was trying to sense whether I was going to rat him out to save my neck. JAMES . (patting the legal folder) I think you got a good shot at beating the case.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: It's that rat bastard from Pittsburgh. He rated you all out. He's been a rat since he got busted in Pittsburgh.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: He's hiding, the son of a bitch, in Florida.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yeah. ’ JAMES I want you and Anthony to go down there and take care of that bastard. Without him, they've got no case.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES'S HAND
dialogues.text: giving a piece of paper to Henry. TILT UP ON James and FREEZE.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: James had never asked me to whack somebody before, but now he's asking me to go down to Florida and do a hit with Anthony.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FREEZE OF HENRY, HEAD-ON
dialogues.text: looking at James. HENRY (¥.0.) That's when I knew I would never have come back from Florida alive. UNFREEZE on Henry and BACK TO ACTION like nothing is wrong. CAMERA DOLLIES OUT and we see James and Henry sipping their coffee. We see James reach for some food. Henry passes James the salt. They are two guys finishing breakfast -in a diner. INT. FBI OFFICE - ANGLE ON HENRY AND McDONALD - DAY 150 arguing. Karen and some FBI agents are standing nearby. McDONALD We'll pack up everything and send it to you.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I got dry cleaning. McDONALD We'll pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a grim James getting into the rear seat of an unmarked FBI car while hoods watch silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen is now seated next to Henry on sofa. McDonald is leaning against the desk. In b.g., we see FBI men playing with the children. We see Henry and Karen's suitcases stacked near the sofa. McDONALD We'll sell your house here and apply the money to your new name.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don't want to go anywhere it's cold. McDONALD I can't control that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I don't care who controls it. Nowhere cold.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: He's very bronchial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see FBI men filling the barroom and Cicero, surrounded by agents, being handcuffed and shoved toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY AND MCDONALD . 154
dialogues.text: arguing. KAREN. (whispering to Henry) What about the schools?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. What about the kids' school? McDONALD Don't worry about the schools. We'll take care of the schools.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I don't want them left back. McDONALD They won't be left back. They'll stay in their grade.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: That's important.

dialogues.speaker: BACK OF HENRY'S HEAD 155
dialogues.text: and TRACK AROUND.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was easy for all of us to disappear. My house was in my mother-in-law's name. My cars were registered to my wife. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My social security cards and driver's licenses were phonies. I've never voted. I never paid taxes. My birth certificate and my arrest sheet, that's all you'd ever have to know I was alive. SLOW DOLLY IN TO Henry's face.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The hardest thing for me was leaving the life. I stili love the life. We were treated like movie stars with muscle. We had it all just for the asking.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES CONWAY
dialogues.text: seated at defense table in grey suit and rimless glasses. He almost looks like one of his lawyers.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Our wives, mothers, kids, everybody rode along. I had paper bags filled with jewelry stashed in the kitchen and a sugar bowl full of coke next to the bed. In b.g., we see Mickey Conway crying.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Anything I wanted was a phone call away. Free cars and the keys to a dozen hideout flats all over the city. I'd bet twenty, thirty grand over a weekend...

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: . and then I'd either blow the winnings in a week or go to the sharks to pay back the bookies.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL CICERO
dialogues.text: looking older and grey. Cicero is looking down. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: as he speaks; in synch, directly TO CAMERA. DOLLY IN TO EXTREME CLOSEUP as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: It didn't matter. When I was broke I just went out and robbed. some more. We ran everything. We paid off lawyers. We paid off cops. Everybody had their hands out. And now it's all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACK DOWN the street.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And that's the hardest part. Today everything is different. There's no action. CAMERA TRACKS PAST white picket fence.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I have to wait around like anyone else. You can't even get decent food. Right after I got here I ordered some spaghetti with marinara sauce and I got egg noodles and ketchup. CAMERA APPROACHES house and TRACKS IN TO:

dialogues.speaker: DOOR OF HOUSE
dialogues.text: As it opens. Aman, still in his pajamas, leans out to get the milk and newspaper. He looks up. It's Henry.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (talking TO CAMERA) I'm an average nobody. I get to live the rest of my life like a schnook. FADE OUT.
